reviewText:
All this negativity towards a game that does perfectly what it's supposed to...

What you get:
- a beautiful, tropical open world
- countless zombies to kill with a variety of melee weapons and a few guns
- crafting system to add a bit of sparkle to the different melee-types
- pretty okay story

What people are complaining about:
- repetitive and boring optional quests that you didn't even buy the game for in the first place
- bugs that have long been solved

Why would you buy this game?
1) You'd buy this game if you like killing zombies, that's the most important aspect.
2) If you like killing beautifully rendered zombies, that's a bonus.
3) If you like to kill beautifully rendered zombies in a tropical paradise, you're golden.
4) If you've got friends who play this game, why are you still reading this, it's got co-op, go on, click buy now!

Why wouldn't you buy this game?
1) If you don't like zombies.
2) If you don't like open-world games.
3) If you don't like the idea of optional quests that require you to do sort of the same thing over and over again.
4) If you have no friends who play this game and don't like open-world zombie killing.

reviewText:
No other game allows you to beat, chop, club, hack, pummel, slash and improvise other deviously enjoyable ways to dispose zombies like Dead Island.

While Techland's Dying Light is a strict upgrade to Dead Island, it lacks the leisurely pace Dead Island provides.
You can do whatever you wish, go wherever you like and take your time to explore every nook and cranny in this game.

To simply put it, if Dying Light was survival horror at its best, then Dead Island is an anarchist kleptomaniac fantasy paradise.

A tip I would like to share: This game is highly moddable. So if you are not satisfied with the field-of-view, graphics, controls, experience gain or even loot drop rates, just go ahead and search for the solutions to customise and edit the game files to your liking.

reviewText:
Who do you voodoo?

or the good, the bad and the zombies - actually this game has quite some things going for it, the story and questing is acceptable done and especially later is astoundingly varied imo, also the atmosphere is well done, not at least thanks to the good music this game has.. apart from the great title song that is ;)
The weapon modding as well as the skilling of your char is also a good point which motivates you to play the game even after you finished the story. Last but not least the co-op part is kinda well done and enjoyable.

But wait, where´s the bad you ask? First the inventory and even more so the weapons menu is a horror in itself (at least, if you play at the pc without gamepad). Also it has still many many glitches and bugs (zombies going through walls is one of the most active i´ve encountered) up to uninspired ctds all the way. Driving of cars and interaction with enviroment also is questionable.

Despite all this, DI offers many hours of enjoyable zombie slaughter vacation :)

reviewText:
Dead Island's trailer (shown in 2011) was probably the most watched one in video game history, showing a family's desperate fight with a group of zombies in a reversed narrative. The final product itself became a bit different of what the trailer suggested: a less emotional, albeit dramatic, co-operative action game with RPG elements and zombies... lots of them.

The game takes place in a wonderful tropical setting in a fairly large open-world environment, on a fictive island of Banoi, near Papua New Guinea. The best location is indisputably the visually striking Royal Palms Resort area, with the beautiful beach that almost comes off the screen and makes you want to jump into the ocean. In contrast, the character models don't look nearly as good as the environment, some of them are pretty plain looking, even though the main characters look better. There are many exciting locations to explore on the island and lots of quests to complete. Throughout the island we can help many NPCs with all the zombie apocalypse themed cliché (getting food, retrieving keys, escorting survivors) but they are surprisingly enjoyable.

Many people criticize the story, but I liked it. It's actually very good compared to other zombie themed games/movies and successfully keeps you thrilled with enough drama towards the end (plus there is a good twist if you pay attention and play the Ryder White DLC which comes bundled within the GOTY edtion). You can play it in single player mode (recommended for the full exploration experience, altough it can get repetitive playing alone) but it's much more enjoyable in the 4 person co-operative mode (with all 4 being different characters). The 4 heroes are distinctive enough and it's worth to try all 4 of them out. They have different strengths and background stories. You earn experience by doing quests and killing zombies (you get extra for killing them in special ways) and thus learn different skills for each playable character. For beginners and for single player game the best is probably Sam B (health regeneration, blunt weapon mastery, knockdown), but on higher levels the most effective is the beautiful Xian Mei, due to her high damage bladed weapons proficiency and instant kill chance (just pay attention to her fragility, she has very low health). She is also the most sympathetic character (she may be an undercover Chinese communist agent, but - as shown in the intro, where she is trying to help an injured woman - she is good hearted and friendly towards everyone throughout the game.

Combat is pretty good in Dead Island despite its simplicity (it's better with a controller, where you can manually adjust the direction of your blows, but the overall movement is more effective with the keyboard + mouse combination), just like Condemned: Criminal Origins, it focuses heavily on melee combat. Unfortunately you can't really dodge or block, but it's somewhat compensated by the fast movement. Observing the zombies' attack animations is the key to success, jumping away and swinging your weapon from the optimal distance is necessary to overcome the hordes of the walking dead. Your attacks can be interrupted (smaller weapons are faster) and if you run out of stamina, you will become defenseless and be likely knocked down. Different weapons have different attributes (there are also rare weapons with better values), make sure to use the ones your character is good with. Weapons (at least melee ones) deteriorate very fast, so you are going to be on a constant lookout for workbenches, where you can repair them. Also you can upgrade and modify your weapons provided you have the necessary blueprints (some of them are crazy and very unrealistic), with which you can cause additional damage, bleeding, shock and poison. Guns only provide short-term alternatives, since you can only carry a very limited amount of ammunition and you can't get any from fallen zombies.
You can also kick your enemies (very fast attack speed, can't be interrupted and uses minimal stamina) for small amounts of damage and if you use is it in mid-air (while jumping or falling) you can knock down your opponent. Also later on you can stomp on the head of you opponent, allowing quicker dispose of knocked down enemies.

If you die (and you will occasionally) you will only lose a bit of money and will respawn near the location of your death. Just make sure not to throw your weapon in a tight situation, because you can lose it this way (permanently). The game uses hubs and will respawn enemies if you leave an area (it can be frustrating when your weapons are about to break, you're low on health and trying to get back to complete a quest). In these situations running (and luring your enemies one by one) is the best solution. Also make sure to use your rage (a special ability that multiplies the damage you do and slows down time) in critical moments, it can really make a difference.

While the game's strongest part is the co-op mode, it's also fun to explore every little detail. For example you can find the family seen in the trailer, adjacent to the room from where you start off. Or a well known character from a famous horror/slasher movie in the jungle area and a really powerful unique weapon nearby :)
The game is a perfect co-operative zombie killing adventure, probably better than Left 4 Dead (storyline) and Dying Light (you can drive cars in Dead Island without having to buy additional DLCs :P), so if you decide to try a game with zombies in it, Dead Island would be an ideal choice.
Also the Game of the Year Edition is a polished version of the game (it still crashes rarely) with collector's edition bonuses and an extra story, the Ryder White DLC (which I haven't played through unfortunately, but it's really worth it as it sheds light on the events at the end, on things that are not as simple as they look).

PROS
+ open world zombie apocalypse with a good story
+ beautiful tropical environment
+ enjoyable co-operative gameplay
+ lots of weapons
+ DLC lets you experience the story from another point of view

CONS
- can crash to desktop from time to time
- some character models don't look good

RATING
9/10

reviewText:
I have seen many conflicting reviews for Dead Island.

I should state I have played this mainly on console but I have played a few hours on PC (mainly a friends to help them through)

I am a fan of this game, many parts of the game are fantastic though some parts do need a tweak. You can choose between four characters:
Sam B: He is the blunt weapons expert. He serves as the tank of the group. He is able to absorb a lot of damage whilst fighting off enemies. His fury skill is punching enemies with increased strength and knockback.
Xian Mei:  She is the blade expert. The assassin of the group she can use edged weapons with amazing speed and stamina. Her fury skill enables her to attack enemies with a short knife in a fury of short stabs and slashes. She has the lowest health of all four which makes her the hardest one to use.
Logan Carter: This guy is the jack of all trades. He is a throwing weapons expert. His fury skill allows him to throw an infinite amount of knives at nearby enemies. Levelled up enough he can retrieve his throwing knives from enemies and make him more effective with blunt and edged weapons alike. He also gains a bonus from using alcohol.
Purna: She is the support specialist and a firearms expert. Her fury skill allows her to use a revolver with unlimited ammo. Whilst guns are scarce in DI, when you find one, Purna is amazing in her sharp shooting ability.

The game itself is split into acts. When proceeding to the last act, make sure you have done all you can in the other acts as you cannot return once you go to the prison. I enjoy the varying scenary throughout the game. The NPCs will have various sidequests such as retrieving herbs for medicine and canned food for survivors. Vendors are littered around so you can buy and sell items. The only quests that drove me mad were the escort quests. The NPCs were often glitchy and didn't follow or they just ran head on into hordes of zombies with nothing but a pipe to help them!! Terrible idea Deep Silver!!

Weapons were taken to a whole new level in this game. You can find blueprints for mods which you can then apply to weapons. Searching cupboards, boxes and everything else will give you items to help you make these mods. Vendors will also have several items available to buy such as batteries or bleach. There are various mods to apply. You can use batteries and wires to add an electrical charge to a blade or how about a mod for adding a flame to your sword? You will find it in DI. Some mods are acquired through side quests. Most mods however are littered about. Make sure to search everywhere.

The story was interesting, a mix of infected and humans to kill. Varied but got a bit predictable after awhile. However the story itself kept me entertained right to the end. It is how I imagine a apocalypse to be. Human against human aswell as against the infected!!

In closing I give this game 9/10. If you enjoy an immersive story with fun game play and a lot of fire blades then this is the game for you!!

reviewText:
I finished this game in over 60 hours and that was a good fun.
What is that game? For me that was quite fresh experience. I'm a big RPG fan so I expected something familiar to me. This is different than typical RPG games. Of course there are RPG elements like leveling and quests, but it's more action game in constantly respawning open world. So you may expect a lot of zombies, dynamic fights and blood. Lot of blood. Fight are mainly in close distance, but you can use a lot of weapons and other items, some of them you craft by yourself.
World is maybe not very big but it's very diverse and you can meet something on every step. Fortunately you can use vehicles which helps on longer distances.
Summarizing, this is just very good, polished and well designed piece of code.

VERDICT:
If you're a fan of zombies or RPG or just good games, try this game and you won't regret.
If you're a fan of Teletubbies, this game will be too scary for you.

reviewText:
Awesome game, it has it flaws and sins like any other game, but the point is they are a tiny little bug compared to the awesome pros this game offers. This game has been out for more then 4 years now, but I have only recently started my adventure with it, and man... what an adventure it is :D

THE PLOT
First of all, this game was largely misunderstooded when it came out, most of the critic was coming from people who were expecting an 'emotional ascpect' in the game, they thought this would be a dead serious drama with rivers of tears. It is understandable as the trailers did create such impression and it was harmful for the game itself. This game is mainly about survival and carnage, and having loads of wild fun killing zombies. There is an emotional aspect in this game, YES THERE IS! The sidequest are located all around the map of the game, you get most of them from people gathered at the hideout but some you must find by youreslf on the map. For example you are passing a bridge and you see a women hiding under a crashed car, zombies swarming around her, she is screaming to you for help, but you can just drive by and dont give a sh*t about it. Or you can give a sh*t and help people you come across, like a women who is trapped in her house with zombies, she is screaming for help from the balcony when she notices you. You go in there and save her. and there are many other situations like this which is awesome cause it gives you a reason to explore the whole map. And lets be honest games like Contagion, No more room in hell dont even have a plot, they are just an zombie apocalypse happend and we must escape, so does Left 4 Dead but it got a strong character story (at least the first part, when you read the comic) and you dont play it for plot. Same is here, you shouldnt play this game for plot, although it HAS ONE! Yes it has a plot and it is in a serious tone, even emotional if you get attached to some characters. There are matters like, naive ideology, taking advantage of the crisis, putting men of wealth before the rest of society, even kiddnaping and  ♥♥♥♥ (not said straight in the game but a grown up inteligent person can read between the lines and from the situation).

Gameplay
This game is an action RPG, a hack'n'slash would also be a suitable name for it. The gameplay is taken almost completely from Borderlands, with some new elements of course. So if you have played that game you will feel like home, as many things are almost identical, which for me is great as I love Borderlands gameplay style. So you can play coop with up to 4 players and you pick up items and weapons in a 'loot system', you have inventory with limited space when it comes to weapons and medkits, and unlimited when it comes to items which are used mainly to craft weapon upgrades or are used in side quests or have a high cash value (like diamonds). So you will find many places where there is a box that has weapons inisde. Also as in Borderlands, the world resets every time you change location, meaning that enemies respawn as well as items and boxes contain weapons again, it is completely normal to any hack'n'slash player I assume. Similar to Borderlands also, characters gain experience and level up to unlock and master new abilites. All i all this type of gameplay is really fun but understandably some people might be drew off by it. I personaly found it awesome as I love to collect weapons, craft better ones and gain experience to make my character better. It is a great motivator to keep playing the game, sth I miss in L4D, Contagion and NMRIH.


ZOMBIES
Well what is most important in every zombie game... is of course ZOMBIES!!! :D
And well I must admit that Dead Island.... has one of the best zombies you can find in gaming industry. They are gruesome and macabre looking. Pound of flesh missing, chewed of meat, bare bones in the open. Everything we love about zombies is here. I am a big fan of Contagion, No more room in hell and Left 4 Dead but the zombies there were just not gory and messed up for my taste, they are usualy pale looking humans with ketchup smeared all over their face and clothes. And here it is a complete different story, zombies are very variated in terms of damaged body and also clothing. When you are on the Hotel and beach part of the game you see zombies dressed in bikini and swimming pants, with cameras on their neck, so mostly you can guess these are (were) turists, later when you are in the city you see zombies that are (were) locals, later on in the jungle you see also more variatons like local tribesmen zombies or zombies in laboratory suits. The variety is pure awesomenes that I never encountered in any other zombie game. And it is also extremely pleasing that there are zombies who can run fast twoard you like Danny Boyle's '28 days later' zombies and some that can only walk twoards you like the old 'classic' Romero's zombies.

SPECIAL ZOMBIES
There are also special zombies to keep the fight interesting (sadly the have only 1 model, exception being the Thug which comes in different variations) and diverse. The first special zombie is the Thug, a big muscle men you might say, a bit higher then normal zombies, he is much more harder to kill as he has more health and can knock you out with every punch he makes which deals a significat amount of damage, they cannot run, can only walk slowly. There is also a 'sucidial bomb' zombie, much like the Boomer in L4D but this one is only about doing damage, he explodes when he is near you. There is a 'raging zombie' a very very big fellow locked in saftey suit (like the ones in mental hospitals) and a Hannibal Lecter like mask on his face, he is similar to Charger in L4D2, he is running twoards you when he sees you to knock you over, his only vulnerable point is the head. You also have a 'drowned zombie' a big fat fellow who spent too much time in water, he spits hazardous 'vomit' out of him to damage you. And there is also the Butcher, who is very fast and can dogde your attacks (melee attacks ar least), his face is chewed of so that you can see the skull and his hands are alos eaten and he stabs you with the bones he has left instead of hands. So yeah there is a great variety to kill here :)

HUMAN ENEMIES
Something that I find most awesome is that not only do you fight zombies but also, bandits (couldnt find a better word for them). This is something that you cannot find in many zombie games and escpecialy not in L4D, Contagion and NMRIH. They are very often armed with firearms, but sometimes they use melee as well.

WEAPONS
They are one of the biggest elements in the game, much much bigger then in any other zombie game I have played. They come with statistics and can be upgraded as well as special features can be added to them. You mostly use melee weapons in the game but of course firearms are also present in the game. But first the melee babies :)
Every melee weapon has a durability stat which is very important because some weapons get broken much quicker then others. When a weapon durability reaches zero, you can still use it but it is very very very much weaker then it was. Of course weapons can be repaired in the game when you use the workshop table... yeah it is unfortunate there is a table and not a guy who does that, cause repairs and uses up money and paying to a table sounds really ridicolous which was a subject of jokes in many press reviews. But once you accept that fact and get used to it, it doesnt bother at all the immersion. This workshop table also plays a very important role in the game as it can also upgrade your weapons to have better stats and also here you can craft 'special weapons' which is made from combining melee weapon with items which creates for example a machete that can electrocute zombies, or a baseball bat with a saw that can cut off heads and arms and legs.

reviewText: I wanted to like Dead Island. I wanted to LOVE it. Not just because it was a gift from a friend of mine, but because it had the potential to be something grand. I mean, let's look at the best details - a number of large open, varied, environments, swarming with zombies, littered with a tonne of weapons and....well, that's it really. Now let's look at the worst details - clunky, frustrating controls, boring dialogue, boring cutscenes, TERRIBLE accents, interchangable characters with tired cliche careers and stories that, in the end, don't matter at all, muddy textures and jagged shadows, and boring, repetitive missions including innumerable little fetch-quests. Not to mention the infuriating zombie-respawning that, in the end, broke the game for us, and we never came back. Dead Island left us both embittered, with my friend developing a life-long hatred for Techland. Sigh.

reviewText:
the Good:  - graphics, sound, voice acting
- large (mostly) seamless environments
- looting, repairing, crafting, upgrading weapons
- xp, leveling, skill trees
- engaging, strategic combat
- cooperative play!

the Bad:  - lacks music variety
- movement is loose & sluggish
- mouse cursor frustratingly slow in menus
- poorly optimized? (I had overheating issues, but not with much newer games)

If you're into zombies, you'll like this game.  It's still one of the best zombie games out there, even with some minor flaws.  The zombie apocolypse is protrayed convincingly here.  As you try to survive, you'll help friendly groups searching for a way off the island, scavenge for more and better weapons, and try to avoid the ever-present dangers of zombies and hostile survivors.  Different types of enemies require you to change up your combat strategies on the fly.  You'll find yourself constantly looking over your shoulder to make sure you don't get swarmed.

Each of the 4 selectable characters has a different weapon specialization and unique skill trees.  It's worth trying them all since the combat and strategies will change.  Single player is great, but it's even more fun with coop partners.  Survive a zombie-infested island with several friends working together?  Sign me up.  Drop in /drop out mutliplayer works seamlessly.  (be aware, there are some griefers out there that team kill)

Beyond escaping the island, the story is forgettable.  But in a game like this, the journey really is the best part.  Dead Island is a solid action first person game with RPG elements.  The controls are sluggish and a little imprecise, but overall the game is a blast to play.  If you like zombies, you'll love this game.  If you don't like zombies, it'll be hit or miss.

reviewText:
Journal Entry 1

I have survived the first few days on this zombie infested island, I've met a group of survivors who im working with to try and find a way to escape. I drank just about every bottle of booze that I've come across and im feeling pretty good. The leader of the survivor group  has given me a mission to travel to a hotel to find help.

Journal Entry 2

In order to travel to the hotel I take a small pickup truck, the steering wheel is on the opposite side of the truck which makes driving slightly confusing at first. Luckily the roads are littered with corpses...living and dead.... There are also fiery wrecks and obstacles so my driving skills won't be judged by anyone nor will I fear a ticket for my reckless steering.

Journal Entry 3

As I drive down the abandoned road im greeted frequently by screaming groups of undead that charge my vehicle. I speed up and bounce them off to the side or crush them under my wheels. I'm not sure what kinda insurance this truck has but I'm guessing my premium is gonna be rough after today.

Journal Entry 4

I have arrived at the outer parking lot of the hotel, I exit the vehicle and can see many bodies filling the pathway before me... I carefully move forward.. out of every 4 bodies 2 of them usually stand up and attack me. I see another one waking up, I wait patiently as the corpse of a young women grunts and screeches. It slowly begins to lift itself to a standing position... but before it can get the that position I run up in a sprint then jump and boot her back down.. I grab my hand crafted snarly looking mace and smash her head in....Groovy

Journal Entry 5

After moving along the parking lot and killing a number of zombie foes im now at the base of the hotel, I am finding lots of abandoned luggage so naturally I dig through every bag and take anything of value. I don't know why we are still trading items for cash as currency during this time of crisis.... but hey money buys me weapons which is happiness" so the saying still stands.

Journal Entry 6

While digging I heard a very deep and rumbly roar coming from a stair well that leads to the lower base of the hotel. I crept over to investigate
date:
It appears to be a large line backer sized zombie wandering around the entrance to the hotel. I decide to take him on to clear the way.

Journal Entry 7

I attempted to do a running kick on the zombie which failed miserably... the kick hardly shook the zombie and left me standing off balance beside him. He looked down from his towering stance and gave me a smack so hard that I was sent flying backwards into a trolley of suit cases.... ok... time to get technical.. The zombie is very slow and very stupid but getting close is where he has the advantage. I toss one of my diving knives at him
recommended: it flies through the air and gets stuck in the side of his shoulder... some damage but nothing that will make a difference. I pull out my mace and do quick touch and go attacks
hoursPlayed: during which I smash one of his arms so hard that it breaks. The zombie now only has one active arm
voteText:
I quickly dodge his attacks a couple more times and CRUNCH! I break his other arm... The zombie then attempts to use a headbutt for an attack... TIZ BUT A SCRATCH!.... I am easily able to get close and after a flurry of repeated headshots with the mace he falls like a tree.

Journal Entry 8

I find lots of money on the big zombies corpse

reviewText:
I can't decide whether Dead Island is the best bad game or the worst good game I've played.

There's a lot to like here. Great atmosphere. Visceral melee combat.

But there's also a lot of awful. The graphics are dated, and the facial models remind me of the lumpy potato faces in Oblivion. Every NPC looks like they're modeling the dangers of skin cancer, all lumpy and burnt. And please explain to me why this tropical resort has such mannish women? You'd expect the beach babes would be hot. But no; it's more like Tranny Island.

The missions outside the main storyline are uninspired time-wasters. The zombies' strength levels up with you; every combat encounter feels exactly the same as the last, at level 1 or level 20.

Building new weapons from blueprints is fun, but spending 15 minutes of each hour repairing equipment is not.

Playing alone is terribly lonely in this game. It's definitely better with a friend.

All told, if you’re looking for a solo experience, take a pass on Dead Island. But as a co-op game, it’s passable, but not great, entertainment.

reviewText: This isn't left 4 Dead nor Dead Rising 2, but it definitely has a charm all of its own,  with lots of collectibles and upgradable weapons,  you'll be looking in every  suitcase, bin and cupboard for those elusive items  so that you can build   one of several   'ultimate' zombie killer weapons.\n\nSo far I’ve thoroughly enjoyed game play.  You've got to be careful when approaching  large numbers of zombies because you expend   stamina when fighting; when it reaches 0, which it does remarkably  fast, you are  at the mercy of all the zombies around you.  If your health falls to 0 you pass out and come to several seconds later minus cash.  Cash is an important aspect of the game because you can buy upgrades, repair your weapons or buy   weapons from other   NPC's or possibly from human players if you play the multiplayer game.  When someone comes online and is in your vicinity (game world wise)   you are asked if you wish to join them in a co-op game.  Well worth every penny IMO

reviewText:
Dead Island is an absolutely terrible game.

And you should get two copies.

I have a very ambivalent love/hate realationship with DI. In one hand, it sucks in almost every way: it's armed to the ♥♥♥♥ing teeth with never-ending bugs and glitches that after a while are just funny to watch, it's got mundane grinding quests, quirky movement, gloriously stupid AI, gloriously stupid UI, a badly designed skill tree, a badly designed currency system, a badly designed durability system, an OK crafting system, ♥♥♥♥ed up driving animations,  ♥♥♥♥ed up shooting animations, a horrible ammunition inventory, a horrible 'Fury' skill... need I go on?

One might say that the Bad greatly outweighs the Good, but let me tell what lies in the other hand: it has great replayability, it is very atmospheric, has a *decent* story, and there are zero connection problems in multiplayer. Oh, and hacking at zombies is really fun, but very, very frustating. Which is why I say buy two copies, or even 3 or 4, 'cause multiplayer is where the heart of this game lies. Playing in singleplayer feels like reluctant grinding, but when you're playing with more people, the game seems less infuriating. I beat the game with my friends in about 25 hours, doing a great majority of side quests, but the sidequests are so boring that I REALLY didn't want to go through them all.

So yeah, I would have to say that this game, while being probably one of the worst games ever, is definitely worth $5 on a sale, because it is unbelievably entertaining with friends. So grab a couple copies, put on your british underwear, and start writing down the most unbelievable glitches you can find (once I despawned because of leaving the game area and started floating in mid-air when I spawned). Avoid cliches like the plague!

BTW: Hold right-click to interact with Jin's boobs ;)

reviewText:
GG but it has alot of glitches

Great graphics, and good zombie fun.

Really, if you liked L4D and wanted more options and a longer (varied) multiplayer, where you actually have stuff to do, this game is for you.

Is it perfect.... far from it.  I have rage quit so many times cuz I got robbed of a weapon I loved, or died because of glitches or Engine BS that cost me.

But when it is good, it is golden.  And with friends, the golden egg keeps on giving.

I plan to give it an honest NG+ runthrough, and might even test out other characters.  I rarely revisit games this long, but I didn't enjoy Riptide on the free weekend, and I had low expectations of this, since I thought L4D was kind of boring...

I know, this seems like a mixed opinion, but the game is a good one, ignore the bad, cuz it is not that bad, and you will really get your money out of it.

Buy on sale, you will be pleased.

reviewText:
That trailer... That trailer.

Im not even exaggerating when I say Ive watched the trailer more times then I've played this game.

The emotion and excitement everyone felt watching that trailer dissolved into a game with no story, no interesting characters and dull gameplay.

Its story is almost non-existant, which works fine in other zombie games like Left 4 dead & Dead Rising but they made up for it with gameplay. Dead Islands gameplay is dull, repeptitive and its graphics are a pain on the eye. To compare it again to Left 4 dead and Dead rising, those games went for a more cartoony look instead of trying to be realistic. For me, Dead Island is something inbetween and the result looks unpolished and unappealing.

Everything about the game feels half done, graphics, gameplay & story. Maybe its my fault for not investing enough time to it but it gives me no reason to try get into the game. It feels like a chore everytime I go to start the game up.

It could never live up to what I hold as my favorite game trailer of all  time, but it didnt even come close

reviewText:
Hey look, a zombie!
And he morphed into the ground...
With my only knife stuck inside him...
And now there's 3 infected coming for me...

For a game that costs $20, there are a lot of bugs in it, not to mention that a lot of the animations could use a lot of work. 9 times out of 10, you will find something weird and glitched that could be as small as a weapon sticking out from the ground to having one of your save files renamed or even completely erased with no reason for it. With that being said, the glitches are possibly one of the driving points for this game, because some of them are actually kind of funny. If you like to see bugs almost every 5 minutes, this is definitely for you.

The game play is a little rough, but not too infuriating. Throughout the story, you will find a lot of weapons, mods and enemies. Some weapons take a little bit of your stamina while doing a little bit of damage (fists, knifes, etc.), while others take a lot of stamina and can blow back enemies (sledgehammers, machetes, etc.). Not only that, but weapons also have a durability to them, meaning after a certain amount of hits (not swings and misses or hitting walls or floors, but actually hitting zombie flesh, be it still walking or completely dead on the ground), the weapon will break or will complete nullify all of its base statistics until it's repaired. This may seem like a pain in the rear, but it's not all too bad due to the fact that you will often always have multiple weapons on you, even when you don't expect too. That does make inventory management a pain, however. Plus, medkits and molotovs are considered inventory spaces rather than sub slots, which can also be a major pain when trying to pick up weapons.

As with mods, there are tons of them. You can make a knife do toxic damage, or a baseball bat do fire damage, or a gun do shock damage. You can also make a weapon heavier for more damage, give it some extra firepower, or make some explosives at your will. All of these mods require items, however, which can be achieved by scrounging about trash cans, luggage, cabinets, and so on. Call it a loot and shoot if you wish, but the looting is far from the best part about the game. Again, though, some of mods are actually pretty damn cool and are a blast to use. This is something Dead Island did right.

As for missions, it's a much different story. There's a lot of cool weapons you can make and skills that can help improve the experience, but you'll often be grinding the same areas just to try and get these parts and xp, let alone for missions. There are certain missions called Continuous Quests". There are almost 10 of these. About 3 of them are for molotovs that require more ingredients then what you actually need to make them yourself. This seems like an act of laziness on the developer part in order to give more unnecessary content for the game. Plus
date: some of the actual side quests seem to take out huge chunks of time just to get some decent weapon or mod that you can't use until 2 hours later when you're done grinding for the parts to make the mod. One of the worst parts about finishing the quests is that you have to go to the quest giver to get the item. This is almost hellish for multiplayer

reviewText:
This game has aged a bit now but I would still recommend it. I have yet to see a better first person zombie fighting game. Almost every weapon you find is melee which forces you to get uncomfortably close to the zombie hordes and your weapons do degrade and eventually break. This combat system forces you to carefully consider a situation before jumping in. You do not always have to fight, if you are quiet and lucky you can sneak by.

Great multiplayer setup as well. You can jump into other peoples games who are nearby and close in level or they can join yours without disrupting gameplay. Fairly long story that is kind of interesting but mostly just moves the game along. Various character classes with different weapon styles allows for some variations between playthroughs as well.

There are a plethora of sidequests to keep you entertained with this title as well and in my opinion the graphics still look damn good. Definitely pick this game up.

Just to sooth any concerns about my knowledge of this game with so few hours logged I have owned this title since launch on console.

reviewText: Exceptionally buggy. It's a lazy console-to-PC port that crashes about every 10 to 20 minutes, with no option to save manually. Effectively a broken PC game. Wait until it hits the bargain-bin (<$10 steam sale), or wait until ALL of the crash bugs have been figured out. I'm uninstalling. As far as gameplay goes: it's basically L4D meets Fallout 3 - in both good and bad ways. It's a semi-open-world sandbox zombie thriller with lots to do, and Fallout-3-like quests sprinkled throughout; however weapon durability is rediculously poor (I hope that gets patched), just like Fallout 3. Multiplayer is broken until they fix the crashing BS.

reviewText: On a small island off the coast of Papua New Guinea, the dead walk. The story didn't set my hair on fire, but everything else makes up for it. Dead Island's strength is in the world it creates. I crept into and through each environment I came to, from beaches to sewers to jail cells. reviewText:
Hands down the most fun co-op FPS I've played. Dead Island has a really good model of how open world co-op can (and should) work.

The fact that it lets you go back in the storyline to join your friends works really well, given that it doesn't really matter if players continually redo the main quest and side quests since it's not a competitive environment.

The combat, weapons, and derpy physics engine make for much hilarity which is really all you need in a co-op game.

Get 4 friends together and play this. Do it now.

reviewText:
This is the first open-world zombie-themed FPS I've played, and damn if I didn't like it. Amazing graphics, really great sounds and music, very good and atmospheric locations -- the abandoned police station, and the hotel, and even the whole town... You can physically feel the zombie apocalypse in this one -- even though it's not as dramatic, as in DayZ, or in H1Z1, or even in games like Deadlight.

The weakest side of the game is AI -- even though you don't expect much from the zombies, sometimes they're just acting... let's say, weird. Another weak side of the game is the script -- god, the screenplay in this one's just awful. I mean, one can only expect as much of a zombie game, of course, but still -- there are good examples of a good script, like Resident Evil, for example.

Game has a lot of similarities with Dead Rising. For example, one can find strong resemblance in finding and crafting stuff, though DI is a lot more atmospheric than DR. Fortunately enough, developers put no bad puns and awkward jokes in the script -- unlike the DR, stuff hapenning in DI world isn't considered as something comical.

To sum it up, even though it's 2015 now and there's Dying Light coming real soon, this is a pretty good game to spend a few days on a tropical island, surrounded by zombies.

I'd rate this game 7.5 out of 10.0

PS If you'll enjoy this game, be sure to check out it's sequel -- Riptide. I did find it pretty good, though I didn't spend as much time playing it.

reviewText:
I think this is a really good game. If you think you'd like killing a lots of zombies in huge and varied open-world environments, finding boat-loads of randomized loot, customizing your character and weapons RPG-style, or all of the above, you will love Dead Island. Bring some friends along for the ride and you virtually cannot go wrong. Just don't expect much in terms of story or quest depth. The game is more funnier when you play it in more people. :)

PROS:
* very nice graphic
* RPG elements
* fight system
* weapon crafting and modding
* open world

CONS:
*The game get repetitive too soon.
* Repetitive side-quests objectives.
*Lack of deepness in Combat
*Weak plot.
* driving a car is difficult as hell
* lots of bugs!

7/10

reviewText:

Game is open world RPG zombies which allows you to free roam. It is probably created to play co-op with friends and have some fun. Playing alone can be a bit boring. Game is worth of money and i reccommend it to everyone who wanna have some fun with killing zombies and playing co-op with friends. If you want to continue the story you will need to buy also Dead Island: Riptide.

reviewText: Does this game have bugs you ask?  Well the answer is yes, but even with those bugs Dead Island is easily one of the best co-op zombie games out there.  If you're wondering whether or not you should buy Dead Island, well only one answer exist to that question.... yes you should.  While not as lively as it was when the game was new and fresh you'll still find plenty of people to co-op with, if that's your thing.  If you'd prefer to play alone that's cool too.  The game doesn't punish you like lots of other co-op games do, if you make the choice to play alone.

reviewText:
Dead Island is a groundbreaking and experimental game in which the developers at Techland try their hardest to commit murder with nothing other than the bludgeoning power of mediocrity. This game is so cool and deep, I got a hernia trying to lift it's emotional weight.

This game is so emotionally resonant that I've had no choice but to start binge drinking and abusing my medicine. I can't sleep anymore because every time I try to sleep I have nightmares about Dead Island.  Dead Island is a black cloud that will slowly consume everything you know and love until there is nothing left.

The laywer told me I can't see my kids again unless I prove that I'm willing to change my ways but I know by now that no amount of rehabilitation will ever take away the pain that I felt playing this game. The doctors have put me on anti-depressants, which have numbed me to the point in which I am no longer able to feel. I have lost my creativity, I have become incoherent and stumbling, and I seldom accomplish anything worthwhile.

I have become Dead Island.

reviewText:
Em sua época de Lançamento, o Dead Island teve um hype absurdamente impressionante. E depois que saiu, o jogo recebeu várias críticas pesadas por conta disso. O jogo não é ruim, mas o problema é que as pessoas esperaram demais e acabaram se decepcionando no final. Eu achei que o jogo foi bem injustiçado nesse ponto. Um outro exemplo totalmente idêntico à este foi o que também aconteceu com o jogo da Ubisoft, Watch_Dogs. O Hype era tão grande que fez com muitos se decepcionassem. Isso não significa que ambos os jogos sejam ruins, mas enfim..

Para mim, este foi um dos poucos jogos de zumbi que lhe passa a real sensação de ser um sobrevivente de verdade! Lute contra várias ordas de zumbi's sedentos por sangue e carne humana em um cenário totalmente tropical. Uma linda ilha, cuja beleza permanece mesmo com o enorme banho de sangue que ela recebeu com essa epidemia. Dead Island possui também uma bela jogabilidade, gráficos lindos e várias quests para se fazer in-game. Eu cheguei a ter mais horas jogadas na versão piratex, conheci várias pessoas jogando que hoje são grandes amigos para mim e decidi adquirir o jogo na Steam por estar em um preço super camarada em época de Promoção. Centenas de horas de jogo lhe esperam!! ;D

reviewText:
Is Dead Island better than Dying Light? Depends what you are looking for. None the less, this game does provide a good amount of zombie bashing multiplayer fun. Dead Island is essentially an open world RPG zombie horror survival game where you can craft and pick up materials and weapons along the way.

I'm conflicted as Dead Island offers vehicles where Dying Light doesn't. Dying Light offers parkour abilities whereas Dead Island doesn't. The map layout for each game is quite different as Dyling Light forces you to move in all three dimensions. Dead Island you are essentially stuck on the ground, but expect a few leaps of faith to progress you further into the level.

Overall, the game play is pretty good. Weapons are available for pickup throughout the game and some weapons can be crafted if the player has picked up enough materials to make something new of it. Weapons can also be repaired and upgraded (visually upgraded too not just some BS stat point). When the weapons are beat up or used, it can be visually seen that they are wearing out. Some of the characters have different stats and prefer either blunt, sharp, or throw able objects. There is also a lady in game who prefers guns over any hand held weapon. They organize neatly for you quests, side quests, and continuous quests. The interface was done absolutely right as well as the map. It's tough to get lost in a quest as it will show you which way to go. Other quests can be completed/ended while being on a single quest (really appreciate this)! The aiming within the game is automatic and sort of points to the limb you are generally aiming at. Limbs can be broken (so zombies can't hit you with it) and even amputated with a sharp enough knife. Stomping on the zombies head is an acquired skill while kicking in general to distance yourself from zombies is available right from the start.

The basic movements are there as you can crouch, jump and sort of jump-dodge out of the way. I wish there was a bit more choice given regarding mobility. Every time you kill a zombie or finish a quest, you are given XP. With this XP you can upgrade three basic chains of skills, rage, weapon specialization (blunt, knife, gun etc...), and survival. I've played the game throughout on xbox 360 and haven't managed to get all the skills unlocked. It will definitely take some multiplayer action to acquire it all. Driving is fun, and the controls aren't the greatest but it does feel good going full speed taking tight turns. Problem is though, there is no other view you can choose than first person. This causes a bit of a problem backing because I have no idea where I'm going. Another thing I've noticed with the cars : the mirrors aren't freakin' mirrors! I know it's a minor detail but being a driver I love having all the views necessary. Within the game between quests, you are able to buy and trade with sellers found in safe zones of the game.

Dead island is visually appealing at all levels. You are in a tropical island resort which itself makes for a good backdrop, but they did their best to absolutely nail the fact that even though there are zombies there, you may still like to go for a vacation seeing how blue the water is. Sounds are pretty good, especially when you hear a zombie coming but have no idea where it is.

FOR FUTURE DEAD ISLAND GAMES : I'm not joking when I say put this and Dying Light together to have a killer blockbuster game. If some elements from State of Decay was taken (such as building and choosing your own safe house location), these games would both be extremely off the hook.

RATING : 7.45/10

ScreenShots :
QTE (quick time events) happen when zombies get too close to you

Oddly satisfying

I'm not sure if one comes with every car

Visual damage appears on the weapon

My friend thought we hit a deer

You can drive but there isn't much to choose from

Not all enemies are walkers or infected

What sitting on the back of a truck looks like. Again, limited view

reviewText:
So Dead Island.

Epic zombie basher game with loads to do in huge world

GRAPHICS 9/10 island looks beautiful

GAMEPLAY 10/10
A lot quests some feels same go kill , go bring me , go kill again.
Speaking about bugs (haven't found any bugs on my play through). i dont know why people cry about them.
Combat system excellent you can cut limbs , heads, break bones, squash heads (like last one the most) ^^ Guns SUCKS enough said about them.
Looting - loads of weps from frying pan to ak-47 (no bazooka, game like this needs bazooka) :(
Crafting - well this one is no brainer u get blueprint and parts you can make nice looking, damage dealing, flame spiting or electricity or poison ( i think green stuff on your weapon is poison..) weapons. Pistols, rifles and shotguns still looks the same or +1 small part in front PEW PEW PEW! still sucks.

CO-OP 7/10 - (my experience) 1/4 of players always AFK , 1/4 of players wants to play alone and always drops out of lobby becoz they want to play alone" (with internet co-op mode enabled) and rest 2/4 players are friendly and nice people (but its zombie apocalypse so DONT TRUST ANY ONE!)

SOUNDS 10/10 - from screaming zombies to music makes you feel like you realy in the island under nice hot sun kicking zombies head in coz some guy from lighthouse told you to do it for new shiny wrench.

OVERALL this game is must have for zombie genre lovers and zombie killers.

And at end - as the great warrior poet Sam B. once said - Who Do You Voodoo

reviewText:
Dead Island is a first-person melee combat action/RPG with zombies. Your main weapon(s) will be meele but later on in the game around Act II you'll start finding guns, but they're not as useful as you would think. Although there's plenty of weapons to choose from and blueprints to find to modify your weapons. The voice acting is awful, the graphics are rusty. To this day it still has many bugs. The zombie respawning is one of the most infuriating things this game has to offer. It had potential but fell way short.

Pros:
+ Exploration.
+ Environments.
+ Some variety.

Cons:
- The game get repetitive very quickly (Gameplay/Quests)
- Lack of depth in combat.
- Boring Story.

Notes:
If you like fetch and point A to B quests then this is your game. It will be more enjoyable with a friend or two.

reviewText:
This game is good..........

I was encased in my house due to a nonstop 2 week long snow storm. I was running out of food..the days were getting colder...i was in so much stress. But then...to my surprise, Steam was offering Dead Island for a discounted price. I then saw the light..Steam has opened up a safeway out of this blizzard. I bought the game and launched it. The game kept me occupied with it's good graphics, beautiful weapon crafting and combat. The best thing of all was...THIS GAME HEATS YOUR COMPUTER UP STRONGER THAN THE SUN'S CORE. I was able to survive the blizzard thanks to the ammount of heat my computer was generating thanks to Dead Island. I am now alive..thank's to the bad coding of Dead island for the PC. God Bless Alah Christ.

Thank you Techland and Deep Silver for making a game that turns computers into Super Novas and keeping us who can't afford a Heater BUT can afford a 2k$ computer, warm during the harshest of times.

PS: Have backup computers for you will need them when this game melts all your chips. Motherboard+ RAM + Graphic Cards + The Rest = firewood, and Dead Island is the spark and tinder.

reviewText:
-Don't mind my hours spent, I've clocked crapton of hours on Xbox 360.
-Review on SP only.
Dead Island is no stranger to the zombie mania. It's a definite win for avid zombie fans and is a reminiscence for the good old times. Dead Island has an array of features not only the brain dead zombies per se but also weapon crafting, somewhat open-world experience and at times, mowing down horde of zombies with a rusty car. It's a great game indeed and deserve the accolade as TMoZG. [As if that acronym exist] On the other hand, unlike the console platform, the PC platform does have it's flaws. In hindsight, the game does stutters due to poor optimization even with a GTX 760. But then again, that's about it. Oh, totally not for the weak-hearted.
Compared to Dead Island Riptide, this stands out. Nothing beats the original that's for sure. Having said all of these, Dead Island does pumped me up for Dying light and Dead Island 2 as a starter kit.

reviewText:
When a game causes my GPU to sound like a jet engine because it is pointlessly trying to push 300+ FPS, and then requires manual text editing of a settings file just to cap FPS with VSync, I can safely say it is a bad port.

If any further confirmation is needed, check out the unweildy weapon selection (using a menu brought up by clicking the middle mouse button, because making use of the mouse wheel is just too much effort for the devs) and irritating checkpoint system.

Then there's the game itself, which can't even get its tone straight - it leaps randomly from attempts at humour to pathos. Quests are mindlessly fetch-based. The story is utterly forgettable. Driving feels terribly clunky. The constant and rapid deterioration of weapons just becomes an annoyance.

It looks decent and has a nice variety of weapons, but that's about all it has going for it.

reviewText:
You know, I would give this game a thumbs up and approve of it as a good zombie title but no it falls short of being good.

What's good:
Lots of melee weapons, long list of mods for said melee weapons, kind of deadrising like, have never played deadrising but I'd imagine deadrising is like that.
Unique concept
Pretty graphics
The Bad:
NPCs all have the same boring tired look to them, and no matter what happens the NPCs all look like they have been constipated for a week and can't smile or show an emotion
A bulk of the quests are all started by talking to NPCs all hiding in one spot of the entire location map, rather then make the island feel more alive by spreading out NPCs
Same dreadfully boring soundtrack of someone sleeping on a low note piano key when you walk into said base of quests
This game has bugged out in the main quest in the lab area and I can't talk to a NPC to initiate a quest in the main quests, probably still bugs out for others too in other areas
Boring sewers that seem endless at times
Every zombie can throw you away and knock you down, I understand the thugs and tougher unique zombies, but every zombie can do this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t
Zombies don't scale to single player so have fun trying to avoid getting gang ♥♥♥♥♥ by 4 zombies at once in inconvienent spots
When you start fighting groups of hostile humans armed with guns it turns too quickly into FPS campaign in a game designed as a zombie themed game, I wish there was more moments of zombies getting involved in human gun fights, also without Co op those said gun vs gun fights are unbalanced considering other FPS games will usually have AI partners involved on your side
You get a LOT of mod plans, but despite looting just about everything I've found I've only been able to pull off the same 3-4 mods.

Summary:
Tries to be co op fun like left 4 dead and fails. Tries to be action/adventure RPG like borderlands and fails. Tries to be like deadrising and comes close, but falls short.

reviewText:
Dead Island is an action game where you take the role of your choice of 4 survivors of a deadly plague that has swept through the island of Banoi. It sounds interesting, a plot that seems to convey the pressure of a threat you need to escape. It, however, is executed badly.

The game, for starters, is only technically an RPG. It lacks several RPG components and any that are in the game are done poorly. This game feels like it has a story at the calibre of Call of Duty. It's littered with fetch quests and something that should immediately turn you off buying this game- No save option. Reloading a checkpoint doesn't even really work. Why do you reset a checkpoint? You do it because you messed up, but no, the game practically stays the same, nothing is reset except quest progress.

The game, however is visually stunning. The glare and motion blur seamlessly blend and make for a great visual expirience if your PC can run the game with those settings.

The gameplay is boring and repetitive and is comprised mostly of basic fetch quests disguised behind a thin veil of interesting back story and the hope the next quest will be interesting. For example, something as interesting as Please retrieve this key in order to do this thing to advance the plot" sounds like something that could end up being interesting but morphs into killing several easy zombies only to kill a massive one and take the key. Alternatively
date: it could continue the boring trend by having you fight massive hoards of the undead only to retrieve the key from nothing
voteText: interest or even adequete RPG components reluctantly leads me to say that you shouldn't purchase this game."

reviewText:
This game may have had some bugs, I suspect many were driver related, not that drivers existed to make the game work when it came out.  Load times are excessive which I'd suspect has something to do with a background process used for the game?  One bug that remains is that users playing with a controller are locked out of the keyboard so they cant chat in game to other players.  There are fixes for this, but be wary, this game is VAC enabled and may result in a VAC ban against the account.

The graphics are pretty amazing, an open world zombie game on a tropical resort.  Perfect for summer gaming, players can get lost in this game just playing it to run around killing zombies in a tropical paradise, the zombie tourists come complete with fanny packs, and awkward tacky bathing suits.  Play as 4 characters and set out on an epic journey.  This game is still active, with people who can drop in to the game anytime or leave anytime which keeps things interesting.  There are tons of sidequests and challenges that thankfully carry over to your following playthroughs, so you can continue working on challenges while playing through the game again and again...  The Ryder White DLC is pretty interesting, not to long, but fills in gaps in the story, I liked playing it after my first playthrough of the game.  The intro for this game is awesome if you never saw it just let the game start and it will autoplay, the game really plays like a zombie movie that your in.

(Even with bugs and no support the game works mostly and is real fun!)
Rating:  10/10  Value:  $14.99

reviewText:
Dead Island is a very entertaining action/adventure/horror game. You take on the role of one of four survivors stuck on a tropical paradise island during a zombie outbreak. For some reason you are immune to the virus which turns you into a most valuable asset for various elements across the island.

Each survivor comes with it's on special abilities and levelling tree, meaning that there is value in trying them all out. The levelling system is good and in addition to this there is also a crafting system to create and improve your weaponry.

There is a good story to follow through the main quest as well as several interesting and rewarding side quests to do.

I would definitely recommend this game as I enjoyed playing it a lot.

reviewText: Dead Island's saving grace is its open-world approach, cool custom weapons and fun coop. Nonetheless, Techland created a perfect foundation for a cool, RPG-flavored survival horror game, but forgot to polish it, in addition to providing a dull narrative.It's the mission design that proves most disappointing. Its scale is highly ambitious but Dead Island's population of living dead aren't enough to compensate for its barren lack of variety and an increasingly tedious structure.Dead Island is a wonderful concept and the core gameplay is executed beautifully, but it really doesn't do anything new or interesting.Dead Island is yet another tombstone upon a grave of excessive ambitions. My condolences to those who fell for that excellent cinematic trailer – it has nothing to do with the actual game.Overall 6/10.

reviewText:
Those three minutes was reasonably talked-about. A slow-motion trailer in reverse order, showing a family at a hotel on vacation in paradise that is being torn apart by relentless zombies. Not only was the presentation beautifully elegant and sophisticatedly unobtrusive in both frame and sound, but the emotional impact was just as downright stirring. The trailer indicated a promising, gorgeous looking game that combined gory zombie action and emotional commitment to characters and story. Unfortunately, Techland’s sandbox action role-playing game couldn’t actually care less about characters and story.

Rather promptly it becomes clear what the game is lacking and most likely will not pay any attention to, namely dialogue, characters and voice-over. Dialogue is flat and incredibly inferior, expressing silliness and stupidity, while wooden animated characters are exclusively one-dimensional and apathetic. Moreover the voice-over component is frequently slack and awkwardly melodramatic, shattering the outcome of any drama occurring, though the occasional scattered tape recordings convey quite the opposite. The simple-minded story basically revolves around you carrying out main and optional side quests provided by a selection of survivors whose common goal is to ultimately escape the infected island. The problem with these quests is it’s easy to detect a repeating pattern that often turns out to be dull and monotonous rather than exciting and involving. The devoid of tension and fateful atmosphere is remarkable during and between the quests that often feel like a one continuous transportation which frankly takes up most of the time, but supposedly that comes with the open world territory.

The expansive setting of an open world coupled with the visuals, however, is mostly a delightful experience. Unlike the repeating gameplay, the dull quests and the stiffly animated characters, the fictional island of Banoi is anything but. The overall settings feel lifelike and appear varied; the environments of the resort, city and jungle come out as believable and are surprisingly detailed and intriguing enough to explore. Thankfully, vehicles (that can be tough to drive and tends to get stuck) are occasionally accessible which obviously make transportation easier as well as carrying out road kills.

Guilty pleasure gradually becomes fun and play a significant role here, though. Unrestrained portions of gruesome blood and gore as well as satisfying versatility towards melee combat against dynamic injuries are the orientated elements that appear to have received the foremost care. Slicing off a zombie’s limbs, witnessing splashes of blood using an impressively widespread arsenal that shortly break yet can be repaired and also creatively upgraded is morbidly awesome, but guns arrive way too late and the ability of blocking and dodging is not implemented and therefore - given the fairly sluggish controls that tend to induces joy kills - somewhat annoying when encountering hordes of zombies and special infected.

Fighting technique is rather easy, energy drinks and bars representing health are scattered pretty much everywhere and looting bodies and all sorts of objects like abandoned suitcases and handbags in order to buy, repair and upgrade your inventory seem endless. Fortunately, the level of difficulty actually increases during the second map, improving the overall purpose of the survival aspect by intensifying enemies; consequently adding fragments of tension. The element of role-playing manifests itself by levelling via talent trees that customise the chosen character. The chance of levelling up is barely a challenge since experience point scores pop out of killing enemies, checkpoints are frequent and respawn factor is quite generous. In addition, killing zombies with friends in a solid online system is a favourable opportunity that actually deserves a bunch of applauds. Oddly enough, if playing alone the other three characters still appear in cut scenes (!), though viewing is optional.

Bringing obvious inspiration from a number of characteristic games, including Left 4 Dead, Dead Rising, Far Cry (not ruling out the sequels) and Fallout: New Vegas, Dead Island hardly achieves equivalent quality. Certainly there is plenty of joyful slaughtering that encourages plentiful approaches on a cool tropical island that has lots of ground to cover, but the non-existent originality, the repetitive quests and lack of weight have a permeating impact on the overall experience which cannot possibly be overlooked. If neither story nor characters are good enough, suspense and atmosphere can actually redeem these shortcomings; however, the redeeming qualities are barely there. When all is said and done, looking back at its easily 20-25 hours of mindless yet pretty amusing content, the game is actually incapable of bringing a single good component, because all it succeeds in managing is a tolerable standard and a tolerable standard alone. Besides, that beautifully emotive trailer keeps teasing in the background, reminding what is left out.

6 / 10

reviewText:
Here’s a game many people probably have in their backlogs and just never got around to playing.  Dead Island really suffered from having an awesome announcement trailer before their game came out. It got everyone pumped up to play a game that looked amazing, and instead they got a game that was just “pretty good.”  It turned out that the team that created the trailer had nothing to do with the team that developed the game. It’s great though, you should look the trailer up on Youtube.

The game doesn’t really have a “main story,” instead it’s about a resort island where a zombie virus breaks out and kills about 95% of the people. The island is actually pretty big and the resort location is just where you start. Other environments include city slums, jungle, and some indoor levels. The game is similar to Borderlands in its multiplayer aspect. People can drop in and out of your games and you can play cooperatively through almost the entire game. Unlike Borderlands though, there is no PvP in Dead Island. I mention the multiplayer here because the game’s cutscenes play as though all 4 of the playable characters are present. For example when people are talking to you they’re talking to your “group.” Your ultimate goal in the story is to escape the infected areas on the island and eventually get off the island itself. By the way, if you have the Game of the Year edition, you should play the Ryder White DLC immediately after the main campaign ends. It really puts a spin on the story and if you wait to play it later, you might forget some of the important plot points.

If you do play through the game in coop with a friend (you should!) you may notice that the enemies don’t really get harder with more players in the game. Instead, each person playing sees the enemy at their level (you see an enemy’s level over their head). For example you’re having a hard time going through the game at level 5, so you call your buddy to join your game with his level 30 character. Well tough luck, because while you see all the enemies at level 5, he sees the same enemies at level 30. However, your friend probably has some awesome weapons and character skills that give him an advantage. Speaking of skills, Dead Island is an RPG with experience and level ups, but the level ups don’t really come with increased damage or health. Instead, when you level up you get a skill point to put into one of 3 different skill “trees.” There are 4 playable characters each with their own different skill trees, but if you play the different characters, you’ll find that most of the skills are the same no matter who you’re playing. Each character does have a unique “rage skill” kind like a hyper bar in a fighting game. When it fills you can activate your rage to super power up your attacks for a short time. The points you put in your skill trees are almost all “passive.” Something to note about Dead Island is that the fighting is mostly melee. There are guns, but ammunition is relatively limited for long periods of time so mostly you’ll be picking up things like knives and axes to hit zombies with. There are about a dozen kinds of enemies (not all are undead!) and they have various strengths and weaknesses, but a good hand weapon can take down anyone if you know what you’re doing.

Some problems with the game:
The side quests can get repetitive. Most of them are “go over here and talk with this guy” type quests and you’ll be running around the island a lot.
The weapon selection system is definitely made for console games (weapon wheel). When you have no open weapon slot and pick up some sort of alcoholic drink, it sometimes automatically switches the weapon you’re holding for the drink. So you’re running through a hall and pick up a beer, a zombie shambles out from the corner and you press the attack button to slash him right? Wrong, you drink the beer in your hand and suddenly your vision is blurred and shaky for about 10 seconds.
In an earlier version of the game (I played the non-Game of the Year edition a long time back) when you beat the game you can restart with all your inventory and skills. However, even though the enemies are your level, the quest rewards are the same as the first playthrough! So you can go halfway through the game a second time before you get a decent quest reward. The same thing happens if you skip a “side quest” and come back to complete it later. The quest reward doesn’t scale up to your level. They fixed this in Dead Island Riptide.

Overall I’d give Dead Island a “mostly thumbs up.” I think the game is about 7 gigabytes and takes maybe 20 hours to play through (depending on what side quests you do). Factor that into your decision of whether or not to give the game a shot. If you have a friend to play through with you though, definitely play it. The coop is fun and makes the game easier in one key way: you can revive your friend if they’re knocked out (and you have a spare med kit).

reviewText: Like many other Zombie Survival games, once you grasp the mechanics of the game it isn't difficult to survive. In that respect, Dead Island isn't any different, with that being said, it does have an interesting story, which leaves you wanting to know what happened to cause the epidemic in the first place. I have to say, it was fun the first time I played it, but a second playthrough seemed rather dull. If it is on sale and you enjoy Zombie Survival games, it might be worth a shot for you. It does get somewhat repetitive, but the characters are interesting to a point so it is at least entertaining. I would recommend it if you haven't already played it.

reviewText:
Before you think I am saying the game itself is bad, it's not. But do NOT buy this on steam.

If you have a ps3, do it there. I had no issue through all my playthroughs for ps3 version. Worst glitch I saw, was a small plant growing or clipping in walls.

The pc version, I lost weapons when throwing them, I have had it crash randomly, quests do not act  right, now I am dealing with enemies falling through a damn floor or running out a area I need to kill them in, which are preventing me from actually continuing.
_______________________________________________________________
THE ACTUAL GAME FLAWS
-----------------------------
A gun is almost completely useless minus against humans, unless you are Purna.
The game says headshots, but takes like 20 headshots to actually kill 1 zombie unless you have a shotgun point blank.

The other flaw, if you chop off a limb mid swing, it still hits you.

Leveling does nothing minus raise your health, and unlock skills.
But since the zombies level with you, they will still kill you in the same number of hits.

PC port is ♥♥♥♥. If you do not own a controller to use, most keyboards will lag your game.
_____________________________________________________________________
PRO'S
------
The game is fun with co-op, single player is ok if you wanna just grind your level up quickly to unlock more skills.
All the characters start the same, but once you max them, you see the difference in their abilities.

Plus modding weapons is fun as hell. Plus the 5 secret dev tools are amazing to use.
All I can say, is if you got friends, a fun game to co-op in.

Console - 7/10
PC - 4/10

reviewText:
Dead Island provides an entertaining pack of arcade zombie slashing with some light elements of role playing. The game doesn't focus on deep story telling and the missions are straightforward. Maps provide enough places to keep it interesting and there are different settings during the game (e.g. jungle, city, ocean shore etc.). The possibility to mod the weapons is nice but most of the mods are pretty similar to each other (i.e. adds poison, fire or electricity), so the feature loses its appeal in the long run. Occasionally there are possibilities to drive vehicles but I found the feature be a bit lacking with poor drivability and handling. I played single player only and I'm guessing the game is a lot more fun with other players.

To sum up, if you're looking for a game that's easy to learn and like to hack'n'slash some zombies then I'm sure this game provides many things to enjoy. Just don't expect anything exceptional.

7.5 / 10

reviewText:
Dead Island is a somewhat-boring game with a bland narrative that I still enjoy, 2 years later (originally played on the Xbox 360).


The story is bland, and only picks up the pace in Act 2. The first few hours will task you with going from place-to-place, performing monotonous tasks that really feel like a chore. Act 2 really starts things up in the City of Moresby, which is my favorite location in the game. You're helping people out, killing thieves and hoarders, saving a girl from a Police Station, going to City Hall, and many other things. Had you given up on Dead Island in the Resort, you may feel bummed out that you didn't know about this section of the game.



The redeeming quality, in my opinion, is the satisfying melee-combat system. In Dead Island, which, in case you didn't know, showcases Zombies as the main enemy, you have many weapons at your disposal. From Wooden Planks, Paddles, and Pipes, to Hammers, Wrenches, Baseball Bats, and Machetes. What really makes the combat system fun is the ability to slice off limbs (which may be a personal bias), debilitate your opponents, break arms, cut off their arms, and even decapitate your enemies. It's something that makes me keep coming back to Dead Island, despite my low time-played (I originally owned this game on the Xbox 360, with many hours played). Perhaps I'm Trevor Philips' descendant, but I find it really fun in a game such as Dead Island.


The map is a winner for me. While the Resort is more depressing than fun to explore, there's also Moresby; the city, and the Jungle; which is, well, the Jungle. All locations are unique, and are a very interesting setting for a zombie apocalypse.


The missions themselves are repetitive; at least for Act 1. Go here, pick up some juice packs, escort this guy, get this Teddy Bear, kill these Zombies, turn on power generators. It's monotonous, and boring. However, possibly from my fond memories of Co-Op (we'll get to that later) I rather enjoyed the Juice Pack mission.

Act 2 changes things up a bit, but they're still a little boring, but not as much as Act 1. Kill survivors here, save girl from Police Station, go into Sewers (which I found very boring), get supplies.


Co-Op  The main thing that makes Dead Island fun is its Co-Op mode. You can play the game in Single-Player, or invite a friend or two. You can have up to 3 other players with you, for a total of 4 players playing the campaign. It's much more fun with friends, whereas playing the game Single-Player might be depressing for some, and scary, tense, and chaotic in the interior sections of the game.


All in all; I recommend Dead Island. It's not perfect, it's definitely not amazing, but it has some redeeming qualities that I feel make it worth the purchase. If you have a strange craving for slicing the limbs off Zombies, or you're a fellow descendant or off-spring of Trevor Philips, then you'll enjoy Dead Island.

reviewText:
This game has been sitting in my library for way too long and when I finally got to playing it, I couldn't stop. It's a pretty solid semi-open world FPS zombie game with some RPG elements and co-op game mode. Although there are few bugs around, you can get through it without any problems.

High selling points of this game are locations - although it's an open world, it gives you a sense of isolation just like the first Resident Evil game did back in the nineties. This whole tropical-paradise-gone-to-hell setup reminds me a lot of Italian zombie movies and you can't miss with that kind of atmosphere.

Most of the gaming time you'll be swinging and slashing with lot of melee weapons. All of them are customizable and can be upgraded to something more, out of deviant Home-Alone fantasy. Game enemies are hommage to all kind of zombies, from classical Romero-slow to 28-Days-Week-Later fast ones, including different special infected that make your life more miserable. Story is cliched, but fun and you'll wreck through Banoi by cutting, slicing and dicing bunch of enemies. Watch where you aim, cause there's gonna be arms, legs and heads flying all around. And LOT of BLOOD. Better put on your party boots, baby.

If you're into for some good ol' zombie fun - grab a headphones, make some coffee, pick up Sam B because it's Coolio with Ice Cube face and scream - who do you voodoo, ♥♥♥♥♥!

EDIT: After playing Ryder White campaign which is part of GOTY edition of Dead Island which tells the other part of now pretty awesome story, I'm raising the grade even more. YOU HAVE TO PLAY THIS GAME.

reviewText:
AMAZING game. I get that the graphics aren't spectacular and that the physical qualities of the Heroes aren't so great either, but that's not what the game's about. The game is about the gameplay; which on my side is fantastic! The intensity of the ambience just really brings you a whole new mood of fear and adrenaline. Especially with the Infected chasing you down, screaming and clawing at you. The Suicider's also bring an awesome feel to the game, with their helpless HELP ME!" cries and general noises of agony. It makes you really wonder how much pain he must've been through.
CONCLUSION TIME!
Great game.
Awesome ambience.
Original zombies.
Original characters.
An enjoyable campaign."

reviewText: This is a great zombie survival apocalyptic game. You can choose from 4 characters (there are 2 female and 2 male). And this is a great point for me: to be able to play as a female character. There is a great story behind each character. And through the story, you collect items to survive, you craft your weapons (melee weapons, fire weapons, bombs, and, of course, molotovs - burn zombies, burn), and create your strategy to kill the zombies and don't get killed yourself. The co-op is very fun and it works. The mods are great too. There's one which you have to survive waves of zombies. I find it very fun to test your skills. How far can you survive?
