reviewText:
Dead Island is a somewhat-boring game with a bland narrative that I still enjoy, 2 years later (originally played on the Xbox 360).


The story is bland, and only picks up the pace in Act 2. The first few hours will task you with going from place-to-place, performing monotonous tasks that really feel like a chore. Act 2 really starts things up in the City of Moresby, which is my favorite location in the game. You're helping people out, killing thieves and hoarders, saving a girl from a Police Station, going to City Hall, and many other things. Had you given up on Dead Island in the Resort, you may feel bummed out that you didn't know about this section of the game.



The redeeming quality, in my opinion, is the satisfying melee-combat system. In Dead Island, which, in case you didn't know, showcases Zombies as the main enemy, you have many weapons at your disposal. From Wooden Planks, Paddles, and Pipes, to Hammers, Wrenches, Baseball Bats, and Machetes. What really makes the combat system fun is the ability to slice off limbs (which may be a personal bias), debilitate your opponents, break arms, cut off their arms, and even decapitate your enemies. It's something that makes me keep coming back to Dead Island, despite my low time-played (I originally owned this game on the Xbox 360, with many hours played). Perhaps I'm Trevor Philips' descendant, but I find it really fun in a game such as Dead Island.


The map is a winner for me. While the Resort is more depressing than fun to explore, there's also Moresby; the city, and the Jungle; which is, well, the Jungle. All locations are unique, and are a very interesting setting for a zombie apocalypse.


The missions themselves are repetitive; at least for Act 1. Go here, pick up some juice packs, escort this guy, get this Teddy Bear, kill these Zombies, turn on power generators. It's monotonous, and boring. However, possibly from my fond memories of Co-Op (we'll get to that later) I rather enjoyed the Juice Pack mission.

Act 2 changes things up a bit, but they're still a little boring, but not as much as Act 1. Kill survivors here, save girl from Police Station, go into Sewers (which I found very boring), get supplies.


Co-Op  The main thing that makes Dead Island fun is its Co-Op mode. You can play the game in Single-Player, or invite a friend or two. You can have up to 3 other players with you, for a total of 4 players playing the campaign. It's much more fun with friends, whereas playing the game Single-Player might be depressing for some, and scary, tense, and chaotic in the interior sections of the game.


All in all; I recommend Dead Island. It's not perfect, it's definitely not amazing, but it has some redeeming qualities that I feel make it worth the purchase. If you have a strange craving for slicing the limbs off Zombies, or you're a fellow descendant or off-spring of Trevor Philips, then you'll enjoy Dead Island.

reviewText:
Love this game.  It's a great zombie shooter.  The environments are beautiful, I'd vacation there!

I have some gameplay video of Purna solo play here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aiEmNJrCe0Q

I had a blast in the single player.  I played all 4 characters.  I would say that Xian was my favorite character, with the Katana.  Purna was my least favorite character because of the shortage of ammo.  My favorite weapon was the Katana.  The controls are such that you can set them to suit whatever configuration you are comfortable with.  The weapons are varied, plentiful and modable.

I replayed the game again in CO-OP with a friend and had a blast as well.  One thing is getting the CO-OP to work was tricky.  What we did was limited our game to 2 players and I set mine to invite only (so a random didn't pop in) then we went into public multiplayer and I looked for his name and invited him.  Not sure why the local CO-OP option didn't work and the join" game didn't work either from the friends list
date:
but instead of wasting time fiddling with it the work around using the public and finding him and manually inviting him allowed us to just start playing.  I also have some co-op play video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K7a3Es1IinE

Even though I have played through all the characters and played a hundred hours or so I still have the arena achievements to get; so even though I bought this game on sale with the DLCs the replay value is great!

Also it's really nice that if you had developed your character in Dead Island you can import that character into Riptide."

reviewText:
What can I say...Played this game from D1 now got it on Steam and it's always awesome.
Good quality graphic, nice envoirment, lot of stuff to kill and a plenty of weapon to use and customise.

The storyline is pretty good and engaging; you don't have the possibility to decide what to do or not (except skipping quests ofc) but the RPG spirit is right there.

Four characters witch specific special abilities, from close heavy combat to long range combat.

You can level up and upgrade your skills and use them to get out from some hard situations.

The title let you suppose what kind of scenario you will find...an island ofc. But there are even dungeon" like houses
recommended: sewers etc...and a city too\n\nThe maps are quite big and there is a lot of missions and stuff to find. Plus a lot of collectibles
hoursPlayed: records etc that will help you to understand better what's really happening.\n\nWeapons are customisable and upgradable (with money and materials that you will find all over the map) and this make the game even more fun. You can literally burn or electrify (or other interesting things) zombies. Plus exploring give you the possibility to find stronger or even rare weapons (like the old RPG school teach us: green
voteText: blue
helpfulPercent: purple
votesHelpful:
yellow and orange items).

Scary factor is always there hidden in a corner...sometimes dark places makes you hard tho see where those zombies are...sometimes you never know what can be round that corner.

Zombies are not equal too...from the classic ones to the thug ones at the runners and so on. In few words a nice way to make the enemies challenging the more you level up and you start to feel too much "comfy".

Sound and music are pretty cool and totally engaging. Changing from situation to situation to hurt the nerves of the most "weak" lol.

Achivements inside the game and outside of it on steam makes this game even more interesting and makes you want to play it again and again until you get all of them.

With the GOTY edition you have even 3 DLC for having more fun Online!

Playing this game alone is good and fun but playing this with friends is even better.

Overall:
Graphic 7

commentsCount:
5/10

In few words...you will never regret this game...never...specially if you will play it with some friends!"

reviewText:
I liked this game as I was looking for a semi-open world, arcade-y zombie smashing simulator. There's quite a large variety of weapons and weapon modifications which you can find, and the loot you pick up will go toward crafting these modifications, which makes looting actually useful.

However, the game's movement is underdeveloped- it feels extremely clunky and slow, and because the game relies on melee combat so often, the tank-like movement can prove problematic.
It also makes the game's pace too slow for such large areas of the map, and it becomes an effort (and slightly boring) to travel even short distances.
The game's voice chat system may annoy some people- make sure it's off, or on push-to-talk at least.

If you are looking for a quick zombie game with more fluid movements, the L4D2 is definitely a better game.
But if you are looking for a slower, open world zombie campaign, then this is for you.

reviewText:
Why this game sucks:

- lame, unoriginal, mediocre story
- blunt, unlikable characters
- cringeworthy english dub (Purna is the best example)
- dozens of technical bugs
- overproduced, damaged gameplay
- no tension and boring action
- weak graphics (draw distance is a complet mess)
- addictive in a negative way
- kills a lot of time
- music doesn't match up with the atmosphere which is still poor on its own
- shopping system is just a fishing rod with a carrot attached to it to lure naive donkeys
- the level of durability of some weapons doesn't make any sense
- everything in this game is boring, even the multiplayer
- this game makes me want to watch the grass in my backyard grow

The conclusion:

Don't buy this game.

reviewText:
A Review Mostly for me so I know I’ve completed the story, as well as feedback on the game.

My Thoughts:- A good idea and not bad for a console port the graphics could have been a bit better but it’s a console port.

Achievements:- 41 of 48 (85%) Achievements Earned

Graphics:- Some good looking graphics can be improved with the Dead Island Helper program. Has some issues with the FOV and the pop in textures but nothing too game breaking.

Story:- you are one of four people on the island trying to survive a zombie type virus, you trave all over the island looking for help and a way to escape.

Replayability:- Multiplayer up to four players, once you complete the story it lets you start all over with your level and inventory.

What Could Be Added: a proper PC edition *this is not the game of the year edition I have so no DLCs*

Rating:- 7 / 10

reviewText:
Am recomending this game to all fans of the genre

The graphics are amazing, the content can get quite immersive and if you are playing this with friends  you will enjoy giggles and laughs worthy of its price.

Every location pressented in the game has been created with the outmost detail and the character that you will decide to play with has it own unique customizations to fit your style whether that is Guns blazings, slashing and cutting through zombie hordes, using zombie heads as a dart board or just smashing their heads in with your own personal medievel tesla nail hammered two handed mace.

There is also a crafting system>? you can craft a huge aray of weaponry suited for your character or your friends from electrified blades to a nailed baseball bat an electric saw blade and dozens more weapons there should be around 100 if not more recipes.

If you and your friends like the zombie genre you will definitelly enjoy an up to 4-player co-op game through the story/side story of the game together.

I was most impressed with the Graphics of the game, the fluid combat(Want to take the left leg off from the enemy go for it, want to break their knees? do it, like to just cut of their heads sure do it, set em on fire, electricute them, drown them, bleed them, hey if you can think it you can probably do it)
and for a zombie survival game i found the story and scenery really fitting, the cutscenes were also pretty awesome.

i've  played through the game from start to finish with friends on a co-op so thats 60 hours with friends that i got so if you and your friend trully are into this type of game you will enjoy it(and if u do enjoy it theres also an expansion)

I've found 1 glitch on the game since i bought it and the glitch was that sometimes the sound of the game when it started it would sound corrupted so i had to restart the game once or twice to get it fixed but if the game starts and the sound is normal it wont cause you this problem during play.

reviewText:
Story
Dead island has good characters, which sort of remind me of l4d characters. They give you  4 survivors and try to give them memorable attitudes and personalities. However I would say the game failed one thing badly and that is to really establish a tone. During the story there was a bunch of up’s and down’s and dramatic scenes but i was not really absorbed by them at all. Neither was i really affected by the deaths of characters.

Mechanics
The looting is pretty good in this game and the benchwork crafting and customization is a more complex system of Dead Rising. Though Dead Rising had a more extreme variety of visual weaponers, this game still does a great job offering a player many ways to improve their current weaponry and future weapons.

Zombie Free Roam
The free roam in this game is pretty good along with its graphics. I really enjoyed exploring the island and what it had to offer. The environments to me were well made.

reviewText:
This game was hyped up beyond belief. The trailers looked amazing.
I never buy games at full price. And when I saw this game on sale, I jumped on it. I was extatic that I'd be able to finally play this game. I only wish I had read the reviews beforehand.

<Summary>
pros:
open world
amazing trailer

cons:
open world
no real story
repetitive
driving is awful
class specialty and specifications are pretty useless
multiplayer is awful (oten disconnects)

<Detailed Review>
This game reminded me of Red Faciton Guerilla.

They tried to allow lots of freedom to the player by creating an open world.
However, they seemed to have forgotten the story.
You get a glimpse of the plot here and there, but you soon forget what was happening in the first place.

The open world is combined with a mission system. You have a base of operations in which people give you missions. With this, you are to venture out into the open world and complete the said tasks. It just becomes a reptitive mess of go to home base go out and get/do something. Of course, you smash a few zombies on the way. There is nothing particulary interesting or different about what you do.

The driving system is awful in this game. You will need to drive if you're looking to venture far in some safety. Yet, the designers decided that driving was an unimportant feature and created a nightmare of a driving control/physics.

When starting the game, you are given 4 characters with specializations. Each are strong at projectile/throwing, guns, sharp objects/something that cuts, or blunt/bashing weapons.
The problem here, is that only one is even remotely useful. The blunt/bashing weapons is what any sane person should pick.
Reasoning:

projectile/throwing (I chose this guy...oops) - Your are given a limited number of slots for weapons to carry. Any object can be thrown as a projecticle. This is great! However, only some objects do any noticeable damage as a projectile. When you throw something, it either lodges into the zombie or falls down. You must retrive it to use it again. There is a perk to increase the chance of items bouncing back at you to catch. So....projectiles like knives stack right? Absolutely not, everything is in its own slot. Recap: limited weapons, some don't do much damage, you have to retrieve in a fight, projectiles don't stack.

Guns - You don't get any gun until you progress a decent amount. And when you do, you have such limited ammo quantity so you want to use it sparingly. Why on earth would I want someone who specializes in guns?

sharp object - Most sharp objects you get are small knives or cleavers. They have a rather short range and would just be better off thrown at a zombie.

Winner: blunt weapons! Most items you find are blunt weapons. The smart choice is to pick this guy.

This just makes me wonder why the game even offers the 3 other specializations if there is a clear choice in who is superior. Unfortunately, you don't find this flaw out until you've played for your first time.

All in all, this was an overly hyped game that flopped completely.

reviewText: A great zombie game undeserving of the hate it has gotten. This is one of my favorite games and it's exactly what a zombie survival game should be. It creates a real sense of survival having to fight zombies with whatever item might be lying around, like a simple paddle. The setting on a beautiful island creates such a contrast to the horrors walking the beaches and chewing up the tourists. The story is nothing unique but enough to keep you interested in what has caused this apocalypse. I actually preferred playing solo instead of co-op as you get more of a horror experience when alone.

reviewText:
Quick review of Dead Island: GOTY!
Graphics are good, game is very well optimised!
Story feels a little bit boring after a while because the quests are usually ridiculously simple and require little to no effort.
The actual story itself feels alot better since it's an adventure across the Island of Banoi rather than finding juice boxes for people that can't even drink. Immersion is great on the Island and city but I struggled to capture that same experience in the Jungle or prison. Very arcadish and combat reflects that since there are a few visual animations that occur (like the amount of damage and xp you get in numbers). Game can feel very repetitive and boring when on single player but if you play with people the entire time (like I did) you will enjoy every second of it whether it's because of the clunky animations, funny characters or the story itself. I played this with a group of people and had probably one of the most fun experiences of my life.
Game: 7/10
Good graphics, good story and questionable (at some points) gameplay.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Overall I'd give this a 4/5. Dead Island is a fun game that is definitely worth playing. I'll list the pros and cons below.

Pros:
-The graphics are great, even years later in 2014.
-The combat is fun and interactive, you can feel the results of every action you put into a fight. You can even run for your life and still feel immersed as hell and have so much fun.
-Awesome wide-spanned crafting system that allows for a ton of fun and even funny ways to create weapons.
-The questline is funny yet intriguing at the same time. The story is very well-crafted and has many ways to surprise you, made even better by the use of the Ryder White DLC which builds upon the story.
-Drop in/Drop out coop system makes for an easy-to-use multiplayer experience. And this game is extremely fun when played with friends. Zombies can scale to your level making it fairplay to go back to the beginning with a high-level character to help a friend. You still get an on-par experience.
-Mixed gameplay elements. You get to melee fight with zombies one minute and then two minutes later pull out your gun and engage
-Glitches. Yes I put this under pros. When you spin around on a toilet and end up on the fax machine, you'll understand.

Cons:
-The economy makes no sense. Money values are all messed up and there is no consistency.
-It's a console port, so the rendering distance for objects and terrain can be laughable at points. (IE i was in a house and the cups on the table only spawned when I got within one yard of them)
-Melee weapons break WAY too easy, and not logically. A wooden bat should break pretty quickly if you spend your day bashing zombie skulls, but it lasts longer than most things. A knife really shouldn't be able to break in ONE fight with a thug, but it does. You'll find yourself kicking zombies to death most of the time once you get through the beginning of the game because kicking is free, weapons are expensive.
-Ranged weapons are mostly useless against zombies.

reviewText:
Dead Island is a fun co-op game that is best played with a partner. Besides killing zombies, you get to pick your character which specialises in the different weapons that are prevalent throughout the game.

The field of view was very narrow at first, resulting in a very fast headache for me.  After my SO modded it for me (from 65 to 90), the field of view became very enjoyable as the headache disappeared, although arms do appear like gorillas. There are also techniques to 'sabo' your friends, by luring them to a corner with a suicider lurking around, or baiting a Ram to rush towards them :)

Overall, a very fun game to play with your SO if you pick a ranged character (Purna/Logan) as you can have many tricks, like enjoying the show as your friends are fighting mobs. (Characters will have a blue outline while in rage mode, and Xian Mei moves like a girl high on drugs.) If your friends picked a melee character and get killed in the end, just stand at the back, activate your rage and spam your trigger finger as fast as possible. Afterwards, laugh manically as you stand over their characters and pressing F" to use a medkit on them at the last second while surrounded by dead zombies."

reviewText:
It's good in some places, and so bad it's good in others, which adds up to double good. You should play Dead Island.

Where it's good? The actual combat is really solid, a lot of games with first-person(and hell, even third-person) melee combat make it hard to gauge weapon reach and often make the combat feel like it has no weight, Dead Island largely avoids these issues, making the combat mostly fun. In general, the mechanical part of the game is beyond reproach(except for that one character who doesn't get any of the weapons she's specialized in until halfway through the second chapter of the game, kind of a misstep, that one, and the fact that the boss battles tend to be over quickly and anti-climactically).

Where it's so bad it's good? Everything related to the storytelling and voice-acting. Do not play this game alone, play it with a friend, play it with two friends, hell, play it with three, point and laugh at every stupid thing they say and do.

If you don't have a friend to play it with? Eh, grab it one day it's on sale and see if it catches you.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Overall a pretty good game, i personally wouldnt buy it outside of a sale but im sure some people would enjoy it much more than me.

Here are pretty much all the issues ive had with the game so far,

- Having to repair weapons feels tedious more than anything i find myself carrying about 3 different melee weapons for no other reason then the durabilty degrades making the weapon useless and forcing me to use a different one.

-When i enter the driver side of a car i sometimes randomly end up in the passenger seat? No idea why

-Zombies can spawn from literally nowhere, a corner you just checked can randomly spawn a zombie and it will attack you from behind.

-A zombie can grab onto you and force you into a short quick time event to knock it off, i hate quick time events of any kind and you have pretty much no counter play to stop this, they will just grab you mid swing of your weapon

-1 in 3 times you pick up a bottle of alcohol it will random unequip your current weapon and replace it with the bottle, and if you try and use your weapon before you realise what just happened you will drink the bottle and make your character drunk. Fantastic. Now you have to open up the iteam menu and re equip your weapon manually. i have no idea why this happens

- Some doors need to be opened with this stupid quick time event thing that has you jiggle your mouse up and down

-While playing you can be given the option to join other players that happen to be playing near you. The first time i did this i was matched with someone who was a 5x higher level then me and started one shotting everything. The game should at least tell you the level of the person you are about to play with before you join them.

I still think the game is really fun, anyone that enjoys survival or zombie games should like this game

Pros:
-The graphics are great, even years later in 2014.
-The combat is fun and interactive, you can feel the results of every action you put into a fight. You can even run for your life and still feel immersed as hell and have so much fun.

reviewText: Most definitely the best survival horror co-op game I've ever played! For me, it's even better than Left 4 Dead. Amazing melee combat with zombies, occasional gunfire with human enemies create an intense atmosphere of survival horror. I think that this game has a really well balanced difficulty. Surely you will die sometimes, but not too often depending on your skills. Lots of different guns, collectable items, modifications for your weapons. Graphics are beautiful, the environment looks detailed. Gameplay is really great, it sucks you in and keeps you for hours! Every single enemy is a challenging obstacle and you have to tackle them seriously. This game is simply amazing, you have to play it and hopefully you will enjoy it! :)

reviewText: Most people slander this game to a point that it turns off the interest of many people, but in reality this is a phenomenal game. The trailer falsely advertised this game, I will admit that much, but just because it's not a super-realistic, hide a in a corner game does not mean it's not great. It's a fun game that allows for much replay ability and hours of exploration. Even the single-player is fun, but I'd prefer the co-op. So many quest and so many weapons, it's hard to not want to do and find them all. A major plus is that you can upgrade and customize your weapons so you can have an arsenal of destruction. There is a vast number of blueprints to find along with other hidden treasures. The game is great, bottom line. It's not  some deep and realistic zombie beat 'em up, it's a jocular zombie  game that will sure to keep you engrossed for quite a while.

reviewText: I will never understand the reason why this game gets all the negative reviews it often gets; to me, this game is more than awesome. It has a small and yet greatly-designed set of maps, interesting characters, a good and handy combat system; it has good graphics and a very small amount of minor glitches; it has a good number of good side missions to go with the very good main story; it offers well-built co-op mechanisms and I must admit I enjoyed playing Dead Island with a friend more than any other co-op game in my life... isn't this enough? Add a couple of incredibly well-made DLCs (the single player set of missions with Ryder as the main character is pure gold, and the twist it adds to the story of the main game is just... twisting) and here's a game I can't help but loving with all myself. Would recommend to anyone willing to play a fair open-world game without dragons and wizards and castles. 8.8/10

reviewText:
Once upon a time there were good zombie games. Resident Evil made sure that zombie games were in the mainstream. As the years went by, the zombie genre was beginning to grow stale. There wasn't a lot of new material and zombie games were usually just co-op. Then along came Dead Island, which breathed new life into the genre....
This is how I feel. I know Left 4 Dead had been out before this, but that was a multiplayer game. Now back to Dead Island. Dead Island has great multiplayer, but it aims to be an action RPG, as far as I know, a first in the zombie genre.
First, the negative aspects of the game. This game is a glorified fetch quest. As you make your way through the island trying to survive and help others and escape said zombie infested island, people will constantly be sending you to do stuff and bring stuff back in order to get any further. When you are playing this solo it gets pretty monotonous. As you go and fetch stuff, you get to kill your way through your fetch quest. That to me, is really the only negative. Also, I don't find most of the playable characters really likable. My favorite is Xian Me, a spy who has a sense of justice. The other three are selfish and only looking out for themselves. Those were my only big gripes.
I saved the positives for last, because there are many. The game is gorgeous to look at. Everything is well detailed. As gorgeous as the island is, that is how gruesome the zombies are. It makes for an interesting clash, as this island paradise is turned into a living hell. The weapon system is a lot of fun, since you get to repair and modify your weapons. There are also shinies! You can look for audio logs and mods to assist you in fighting or in learning more about the story. This is a fun game for multiplayer. When you play it with others, it doesn't have the monotony of playing single player. While I don't particularly care for most of the characters, they have very interesting skill sets, challenging you to not always go around with guns blazing. There is also the RPG aspect. Each character has three skill trees that they use. You can focus on causing damage, being stealthy, or being healthy (medkits heal more etc). Whats really great is that once you beat the game, your character and everything he/she has learned will transfer to Dead Island: Riptide.
While this game can feel monotonous, especially for the single player, the pros really outway the cons. Dead Island really helped the zombie genre and it is definitely worth the playthrough. Get some friends together and have some fun with this one!

reviewText:
To put it simply, Dead Island is a pile of trash on almost every front, that is only successful because of the immense hype before its release. The initially satisfying melee combat becomes tedious and boring within a few hours due to its lack of complexity, and while I see how they were trying to make fighting zombies a taxing endeavor, it just ultimately adds to the monotonous nature of the game and becomes its most prominent flaw. The RPG elements are extremely shallow, and don't add much needed nuances to combat; every fight ends up being a overly long swing-fest. There aren't enough enemy types to keep the combat fresh, and you don't gain enough abilities from the level up system to feel like you are actually becoming stronger.

Every other aspect of the game, including the physics, user interface, visuals, sound and writing are so pathetic that its actually humorous. It's very common to see ragdolls working improperly, the vehicles getting stuck on nothing; it took no effort on my part to actually get a chair to levitate. The pause menu is atrocious, and a chore to navigate, which makes leveling up, managing your inventory and upgrading various items and weapons agonizing. In the visual department, the render distance is probably the biggest issue, where objects will appear as close as 10 feet away while driving, and emerge from an uncomfortably close wall of fog. The animations are assanine, nonsensical, some of the worst animations I've seen in years. The textures and skybox both break quite often. Dead Island lacks a memorable score, and has some of the worst voice acting I've heard from modern video games. The story is indescribably bad, which wouldn't really matter if the game didn't sell itself as a dramatic zombie apocalypse story, which is a tired concept that has been milked to death, and most of the time has been executed poorly.

This game isn't worth 5 dollars, I wouldn't say its worth 3 dollars. Please don't buy this game. If you have any sort of standards in games, or at the very least in what you pay for, don't give the horrible developers of this piece of garbage game your money.

reviewText:
A tropical paradise full of zombies sounds interesting? Then you should try out this game.
The game provides 20+ hours of zombie killing, along with a variety of weapons and partially beautiful open-world settings.
Most part of the gameplay you have to solve quests and have combats against zombies, therefore you will certainly not get bored when playing Dead Island.
The game also includes a 4-player mode that allows you to play online with your friends.
Dead Island has its drawbacks as well. It can happen that the npcs get stuck and you have to restart the game, which can be really annoying. Also, the game has several texture glitches that interfere with the overall gaming experience.

In conclusion, if you are looking for an open-world survival game to enjoy with friends, then Dead Island is certainly not a bad choice.

Sound 8/10
Graphics 9/10
Gameplay 7/10
Atmosphere 8/10

reviewText:
I don't know if anyone will even be looking for reviews of this game by now, but I'm really surprised this game has such good ratings for what it is. Personally, when I play this, I feel like I'm forcing myself to look for the positive aspects to try and find a reason to keep playing.

I never gave this game too much attention when it was first released, but recently I've been feeling short of things to play and it was recommended to me by a friend, who called it quite similar to a few games that I do like. I'll start by saying the game looks alright on high settings, and I've noticed a couple of neat features like fairly realistic weapon degrading rates with visible damages on the weapon, and the door barging system. However, the game feels probably the most watered down a game has ever felt to me - loot respawns every time you load up your save, you can't repair weapons with similar or identical ones and instead you have to pay to repair them at a workbench, it seems new weapons are set to auto equip if the level requirement for it is higher even if it's a weapon which isn't as effective as your current weapon for your character, and forced lock on messes up what would otherwise be decent melee combat. The worst part is that none of these annoying features can be changed or disabled. The inventory screen also functions quite poorly, and the shadow of your character looks absolutely ridiculous in every sense of the word - I'm astonished that this last issue hasn't been patched as it's completely laughable.

Overall, for me this game is disappointing considering how good it's made it out to be. If you're looking for a game which is immersive and realistic or exciting and rewarding, I strongly advise you to look elsewhere.

reviewText: A couple flying to the vacation of their dreams is torn apart by a violent plane crash. Take on a harrowing quest to find your lost wife. Enter into the dark world of a devastated tropical paradise now plunged into chaos. It's a place where the word dead" has an entirely new meaning. Face the nightmare and fight for survival. Explore the secrets hidden in the darkest regions of the island and fight your way through. Survival is your main goal! Dead Island is a non-linear FPP (First Person Perspective) survival horror title. The ultra-realistic combat system will ensure that every confrontation is a thrilling experience. Use anything you find in your surroundings as a weapon. Make decisions that influence the entire world around you. Take advantage of opponent behavior and game physics. Dead Island is a mix of intense action and chilling horror environments in an engaging

reviewText:
I actually spent a lot more time on this game than I thought, and so I will credit the game for it's replay value.
Sure, some of the missions feel like a waste of time, time that could be better spent idling for your Team Fortress hats, but in the end, it all comes down to you enjoying ripping zombies apart with a baseball bat, or an electric katana.
The developers weapons make this game even more fun, my favourite being the homerun baseball bat.

Killed my sense of morality,
10/10.

reviewText:
Another game I played mostly offline (as if nine hours is the total time it took me to complete it three times...) because it's a good game - although not everybody agreed on that, it has to be said. The trouble that I found with the game (apart from the bug where it deletes your save game without asking you) was five-fold.

1) There really wasn't much point in levelling up - the zombies (or sick people, whatever) level up too. Levelling up just makes your pride 'n' joy Cutty-Stabber 3000 that you made with batteries and duct tape and the hairs from a unicorn's backside useless after you've levelled up a bit. Meaning that you have to make the weapon again. Making the whole thing a bit repetitive.
2) The entire game is best summed up in fetch and carry terms - go here, get this, come back, go to the house NEXT DOOR TO WHERE YOU JUST WENT, get another thing, come back... rinse, repeat. It's circular and boring.
3) Unless you have lots of bullets, or you unleashed your inner Viking and went for the throwy character, prepare to get knocked over a lot and to die a lot. You go down so easily the zombies could strangle you with a cordless phone. (As Pablo Francisco might say if he played the game.) Dying means that...
4)... You could well lose your precious stuff, and, after searching for it like a demented Hobbit, you'll discover to your shock that it really is gone. Time to start saying the Northman prayer from The 13th Warrior as you rock back and forth. With the loss of your Cutty-Stabber 3000, it'll be a small matter (apologies to those who unaccountably haven't seen The 13th Warrior).
5) If you do happen to choose the throwy character, prepare to have the game forget your weapons. Yep. Sometimes, they just disappear. Like a one night stand at dawn. You're left with nothing but memories now, and, more pressingly, fewer weapons than you had a second ago.

In spite of all of that though, the game is still great and it's still worth playing. I would recommend it to anybody that likes beating up on zombies wearing holiday gear - just watch out for those beach balls!

reviewText:
Dead Island is a game that aimed to capitalize on the recent zombie game craze and while it does attempt to do so a little outside the usual genres it quickly begins to feel very familiar.

Dead Island starts you off in your hotel room a small tropical island after one hell of a night. You quickly discover that a zombie plague has swept the island overnight and you must now do what it takes to survive with only a mysterious voice on the radio to guide you.

Dead Island is a zombie hack and slash much in the same way as Dead Rising. You find various weapons and items that can be used as weapons and go beat the nearest zombie with it, as you progress you will also find blueprints for combining and improving your weapons. The combat feels very meaty and there is a good deal of satisfaction in hitting a zombie just right, taking off an arm or a leg. Unfortunately this does not scale with the progression very well and once you start to get into the high levels combat becomes increasingly frustrating and predictable.

The storyline takes you across several large, but not equally populated with content, maps where the mysterious voice guides you towards both escaping the island and finding a cure. Along the way you encounter other survivors that will trade with you and send you on various side-quests.

This leads to what is perhaps the biggest weak point of Dead Island, the characters. The storyline is not bad by itself, it certainly isn't great either but it's good enough that it won't bother you too much. The characters however are some of the most poorly written ones I have ever encountered in a video game. Although quite a few of them are simply blank slates that exist solely to send you on missions a number of them try to connect with you and it just fails horribly. This is most notably when you get a bit into the game and are starting to get ready to leave the first map when the game introduces a new unplayable sidekick to you and from there on in, every time there is a cut scene or a bit of storyline the game will attempt to make you form an emotional connection with this girl. And it just doesn't work because she is just as big of a blank slate as the rest of the characters. In the end it only serves to make you resent the storyline and to quickly skip past any dialog for fear of vomiting.

Dead Island is at it's core a multi-player game. Although it can be played, and completed, single-player the game is setup with a drop-in/drop-out system of multi-player where you can at any time go play with someone of similar progression or have someone come into your game to help you. Although the coop is nice the poorly implemented group questing system as well as the frequent timeouts keep it from being as enjoyable as it should be.

The graphics has it's ups and downs. While the backgrounds of the scenic tropical resort are gorgeous and the game in general manages to pull off the tropical island look quite well, even in the less tropical parts of the game, the rest just isn't up to spec. The characters, the weapons, the buildings just all seem like they were taken out a game several years old and it hurts what little immersion the storyline didn't manage to kill already.

All in all, Dead Island is a game that's quite fun for the first 20 levels or so if you can manage to look past the extremely unlikeable characters but whats good about the game tends to disappear towards the endgame and it becomes just another grind towards completion.

Dead island is a beautiful zombie open world game. Game is taken place on an island an your mission is to escape the island. The gameplay was amazing. Has the Borderlands concept with the levels. The gore system is pretty cool and the customization with weapons is what makes this game fun.

Pros
custom weapons
Driving cars
Huge maps
4 characters to choose from (5 if you have DLC)
plenty of small secrets
side missions

Cons
driving is just terrible
Bugs: Survivors are sometimes giants instead of normal size humans

reviewText:
I beat this game with every character and yet I'm still totally addicted to it.

If that's not a glowing reference for how awesome this game is, I don't know what is.

There's just something perfectly relaxing about the tactics for killing zombies in this game. Awesome for getting out daily aggression by jump-kicking them head over heels and then bashing or stomping their squishy heads while they lay stunned on the ground.

The game's atmosphere is fantastic, with a great combo of tropical vibrancy combined with creepy, dim places where zombies can creep up on you and scare the living crap out of you.

The controls seem a bit wonky at first, with a bit of a delay on character movement, but to me that makes it feel a bit more realistic than most FPS games do. You can't just strafe back and forth smoothly, changing direction on a dime in real life, after all!

A lot of peoples' complaints are about weapon deterioration and how much they hate it, but I think it's a great game mechanic, forcing you to think before you just wade into a pack of zombies swinging your nice, shiny machete. It adds tension to each encounter, instead of just letting you mindlessly hack your way through the game with zero consequence. Sure, it may not be realistic in terms of how quickly the weapons break down, but that's not really the point of the mechanic. Plus, let's face it, the zombies aren't exactly realistic either, now are they? Seeing as how zombies don't actually exist and all... Seems a bit arbitrary to find fault with one unrealistic thing, but not another.

Anyway, this game is amazing and highly replayable, with a great storyline and enough zombie-killing fun to make even the obnoxious back-and-forth side quests entertaining to do. If you don't own it yet, you're doing yourself a disservice and should really get on it. Especially if you have friends that you game with. 4 player co-op y'all!!!

reviewText:
Okay this is gonna be a long one. So get ready....

Dead Island, a game released in late 2011. This game is one of the better zombie survival games with great textures and graphics especially for its time. I'll say this now, the graphics are like Far Cry 4's graphics (kind of). Anywho, what made this game actually a good zombie survival is the multiplayer feature. Because of this multiplayable feature more people got it to play with their friends. Now to get to the actual part of the review.

This game has a great campaign but what really makes it good is if you have friends to play campaign with you. I guess its kinda bad that your campaign doesn't get updated or progress if your playing on another person's campaign but I guess its okay.  This could really do well if it didn't crash so often. That was one of the downers of the game and still hasn't been fixed yet.

Also the mods or DLC you can get with this game is amazing! All the blueprints you can make and use against zombies are just so satisfying and one thing this game has is BASIC GAME LOGIC! Anyway i'm just gonna end the review here.

9/10 Ducks

reviewText:
Quick summary: Game is great fun, but play dying light instead, its very similiar but more fun.

Full review:

This game is fantastic.
its a fantastic open world, where you can make awesome weapons, explore and smash zombies heads in with electrified machetes.

Its a good campaign, challenging, exciting.

My only gripe about this game is that there never feels like much of a character progression.
As you rank up you gain XP for new skills, which are all very useful. but with weapons, even though you constantly find new and more powerful ones as you go through the game, the zombies have gotten more powerful too so it makes no difference.

Its a pretty fun experience if youre playing solo, but playing with friends in coop is an absolute blast.

However techlands new zombie game 'dying light' is in a LOT of ways the same as dead island, the weapon system, the skill system, even a lot of the enemies.
However dying light takes out a lot of the stuff that made dead island less fun and fixes it, so if you have a choice between the two, play dying light first,  its a lot more fun.
Both games are fantastic though. Would highly reccomend

reviewText:
Being a zombie fan, like many others out there, I wouldn't miss a game like this.

This game has (almost) everything a zombie game should have: it's open world, it has survival elements, crafting, various weapons and upgrades and different classes to choose from. and, the most important thing for a game like this - it's designed for co-op.

The graphics are great, something that was to be expected (but not guaranteed, of course) since the action takes place on a resort island with fancy hotels and crystal-clear water. The physix also adds a lot to the overall gameplay and feeling.

The world is huge and you will have the chance to explore every corner and do a lot of main and side quests while facing different enemy types.

Unfortunately there are a couple of downsides.

First downside is the feeling. Although the game looks great and the atmosphere is cool, it's not something you would expect from a survival game. It's all too cheerful and colored. It make sense since you're on a tropical island but not when you start thinking this is a post apocalyptic game. Sure, when you go indoor, everything changes and it all gets creepy very fast but you are not spending too much time indoors.

Second downside is the biggest issue. It's good that the game has a huge world but unfortunately it's way too repetitive. It's easier to play with someone but this doesn't change anything.

Both issues would have been partially solved if you would have been given the opportunity to spend more time indoors and less outdoors.

I really enjoyed the game but I was unable to play for long because of these.

8/10 potatoes from me.

reviewText:
I'll just list off pros and cons about this game, so yeah.

Pros:
+Fun Combat
+Four characters with different skill trees (Think of it like Borderlands)
+Co-op (If you have no friends to play this with, the game has a system in which it offers you to play with players in the same part of the game as you)
+A lot of weapon modifications
+Zombies, of course.

Cons:
-Glitches (I was bugged in the same place and couldn't move, some important enemies wouldn't spawn which would bug the quest, etc.)
-Sometimes repetitive quests (Missions where you had to fetch x and y, yadda yadda)
-Mediocre story

That's about it. If you want a solid zombie game to play alone or with friends, this is the game for you.

I r8 8/10, gr8 game m8s.

reviewText:
This game is average.

As far as the game play goes; it's seemless, atmospheric, and can get very fun. The weapon mods and character specialities help give you a bit of variety. Although you don't find guns until about halfway through the game so good luck starting with that guy. I simply call it average because it doesn't offer anything interesting to the zombie outbreak genre. The story is very mediocre and pulls all the cliches, including a nonsensical climax that'd make Umbrella envious. And yes, there is a sewer level. There's always a sewer level. Also it felt like the game hinges on it's co-op to help distract from the (lack of) story pacing and endless fetch quests. Which it did exceptionally well when I was playing with others.

If you have a group of friends that like to mess around; you'll probably enjoy this game.

If you want an engaging Walking Dead drama; the cake trailor is a lie.

reviewText:
Price / hour: <0,51€ (I'm going to play this alot more)

I really don't like zombie games. Half of them are hack 'n slash type of games, you just kill them and kill them and... just no sense. Another half is surviving with few ammo in a wasteland, ehh.

Dead Island is different, it has a point and a good story. It clearly shows the point what is going on and where you have to go and it's AWESOME adventure. It's one of a kind; adventure + zombies. That's maybe why I like it so much. I see no point to go to play Riptide or any newer first, because this game works absolutely fine.
-     And this game has perfect amount of challenge. You can choose your difficulty to automatic which generates the enemies based off your success rate. Money is limited, but not too limited, it's perfect. Altough, I found a glitch with my friend that you can give some certain weapons to your friend and it duplicates. But who said you have to use it, eh.

And the main point for being one of my favorite games: Co-op campaign. Like, seriously. Who wouldn't want to play HL2 as a coop, for example. Yes, there are mods for them, but they are not automatically part of the game and they are buggy. Dead Island has it inside of it, and it even supports 4 players without problems! And like I did; I firstly completed it   1/3, and then my friend got the game and I played it to the same point. Also I moved my items on this point from my another character to the character I played with my friend. And it was equally fun at both times. I JUST LOVE THIS GAME!

reviewText:
Dead Island was pretty hyped before its release in 2011, partly due to the phenomenal and emotional trailer released in the months prior release. While the game doesn't contain the kind of emotional content depicted in that trailer, Dead Island is definitely no pushover.
The game is set on a tropical island called Banoi, where you can choose to play as one of four survivors, all with their different strengths and abilities. Each class is catered to a specific weapon type, so the player is rewarded for using their playing style. You can sprint, kick, and bash zombies whilst running through abandoned resorts, defunct hotels and bloodied swimming pools.  I liked the location and the silly/humorous approach to a zombie game.
The trailer made players expect an emotionally rich game with focus on characters. While I did like this game, there is little to no story, and the characters are little more than cardboard cutouts for different abilities. The game plays out like Dead Rising, and the silly yet gratuitous gore is nothing like what you'd expect from the trailer.
Speaking of Dead Rising, the game allows you to craft all kinds of weapons; spiked baseball bats, flaming axes, electric knives, electric fisti-cuffs, enhanced assault rifles and much more. There are loads of weapons to make using the game's crafting system, and it was really enjoyable to make/buy new weapons and test them on the zombie horde. There are also different types of zombies to fight, all of which require different tactics and weapons to defeat.
The island itself is fairly large, and quests range from tasks such as collecting supplies, wiping out zombies and rescuing survivors. The XP system and rewards bonuses gives the player incentives  to complete missions, and you'll also end up finding a fair emount of loot on missions. The best way to describe this game is Borderlands with zombies.
The game is quite solid and is okay visually, but there are fair amount of bugs, especially with AI and quest markers. I've encountered zombies that completely ignore the player or even get stuck in terrain. Quest markers are also quite dodgy, meaning you'll end up going the wrong way and missing your objective completely.
Overall, Dead Island is a solid and enjoyable title. It provides similar action RPG fun reminiscent of Borderlands, but could be improved with a great story/characters as well as additional work on bugs and glitches. This is definitely worth a playthrough either by yourself, or with a few friends via the great co-op mode. 7.5 / 10

reviewText:
[Dead Island] [Sentinel] [21/06/14]
[Store: £9.99]

Dead Island is a beautifully detailed game, it focuses around you the (main character). Who was going to enjoy a lovely holiday in what I think is a paradise.

You will have to do what you can to collect supplies and to meet up with other survivors in the world, doing this is not easy, you will be facing multiple challenge’s along the way, sometimes even a quest within a quest, to obtain the primary objective.
Just make sure you escape the dammed island.

[PROS]
-	Beautiful graphics and wonderful scenery.
-	Great crafting system.
-	Huge supplement of weapons.
-	Hours of campaign to play.
-	Vehicles to drive.
-	Play with friends (Co-Op).
-	Large open world.

[CONS]
-	Endless barrage of zombies constantly spawning.
-	Too little ammunition for guns.
-	The XP levelling system.

[OVERALL 7.5/10]

reviewText:
Dead Island

Positives:

+ I'm not a fan of the zombie game genre, but even I enjoyed this. That has to be a positive right?
+ Huge variety of weapons to use, including but not limited to: meat cleavers, baseball bats, crowbars, knives, machetes, cudgels, police batons, magnum pistols, shotguns, rifles...the list goes on.
+ A lot of modifiable weapons, where you can add electronics to electrify enemies or set them alight with fire - that's just the tip of the iceberg!
+ Awesome, gory, satisfying combat. You can sever the limbs of zombies or decapitate them. It's brutal and it's cool.
+ Good storyline, I really enjoyed it.
+ Skills system whereby you gain new abilities each time you level up. These abilities are very helpful in the game. Just some of the unlocks are increased damage output with specific weapons, increased stamina and additional benefits to fury mode (where you can go beserk and hit multiple enemies in slow motion with throwing knives or bullets from a gun, depending on your character's speciality.
+ Nice graphics, although they could be improved as well.
+ Co-op mode so you can play with friends or other people you don't know.
+ 50-60 hours of gameplay (Singleplayer) for completionists who visit all locations and complete every side quest.

Negatives:

- My character seems to walk very slowly for no reason. There is a sprint button, but the default walking is annoying. However, as Dead Island's story progressed and I became engrossed in the gameplay, this bothered me less and less.
- Mouse sensitivity is bad. If you change it for the gameplay, it affects the menu display. So the in-game sensitivity will be perfect, but the menu will be extremely slow. You'll regularly be checking your inventory to switch weapons or searching through your list of available quests and this sensitivity is irritating. Once again, as I ventured through the game, this problem became less noticeable and didn't bother me, but I must list it as a negative nonetheless.

Overall Score: 8/10

Dead Island is a thoroughly enjoyable experience, especially for zombie genre  fans. I definitely recommend it.

reviewText: Dead Island is an awesome FPS/RPG with lots of loot, craftable weapons, intense in your face melee action and an impressive multiplayer drop in function with up to 4 players playing co-op.  You're stranded on a beautiful resort island when the zombie outbreak happens and you must find a way out.  You'll find the typical RPG quests here, however, the action is really what kept me going in this game.  The in your face action is intense.  Since most weapons are melee and gun ammo is sparse, the majority of the action will constantly be close ranged.  There are a few bugs throughout the game, however, nothing that prohibited me from finishing the game.  Overall a great zombie experience.

reviewText:
it's very troubled in dark heart and the fallacy of anthropocentrism that place mankind's existance at the central of natural order. like the foliage  asserting itself over brick and steel, the mindless drive to exist, becomes it's own form of zombification. complete with desperation,denial, and terrifying justification. With fightng the feeble authority of the establishment and offering the uncertain hope of a better future in dire times.

the narrative advantage of games is fully realised with no equal in the media. The characters are so accustomed to lost, that you se their faces fighting back actual feelings, embracing their facade come from moments as gentle as a watch.
It's how the gameplay perfectly integrates in design and tone, that sets the game apart and overcomes the frequent issues with Iincompetance in major releases.

The player is simmering with range that circumstances, excused by the venire of survival, defines his violent nature and snacks the player up in the moment willing or not.

The dire noxious tension, that at times envokes dark souls is only relieved by dispatching these living obstacles to the goal of making through one more moment. There's something momentarily releaving and viscerally satisfying, but then gives weight nauseating implications of the act.

Techlands's awareness of the violence and it's unflincing intrusion of the player's psyche, is a necessary recalibration of the role in violence in games, that will undoubtedly be part of the ongoing debate in the media.

reviewText:
Wave upon wave of demented avengers march cheerfully out of obscurity into the dream.




One of the few things that I dreaded was that this game would quickly become repetitive and boring. Luckily, the combat delivers.

I'll make this a short and sloppy review for once.

The negatives

1. The lip sync of NPCs is nonexistent.

2. No DX10 or very high video settings for the PC version.

3. Not entirely an open-world game, not the first Act at least. The map is shrewdly designed to give the impression that you can go anywhere. The cleverly confined coastal areas and the cleverly confined inland areas (with mountains on each side, ahem ahem Red Faction Guerrilla, ahem ahem, Far Cry 2, ahem ahem Lost Planet 2....) prevent you from going where ever you want. However there are large areas that can be traversed in almost any direction. Also, when you venture too far out it says You are leaving the playable area" which gives you several seconds to get back before you die
date: for whatever reason. You also cannot swim so when you go into the deep water you just start walking on the bottom without being able to see anything
hoursPlayed:
you will die from going too far out instead of dying from drowning.

4. The zombies do not have to die from the blows or trauma to the head. You can just beat them to their second permanent death.

5. The enemy and friendly NPC's are not that numerous.

6. The only dramatic moment in the game is when that family gets slaughtered...in that trailer...for the game.

7. You cannot turn off the cross-hair
voteText:
so if you plan on playing in 3D that cross-hair will mess up your 3D effect.

8. No save feature. You can't always re-enter the game if you press alt-tab. This will cause you to end the game through the task manager and start from the last checkpoint.

9. The enemy bodies disappear within a minute or so when you turn around.

10. The stamina bar does not pop into the middle of the screen all the time and stay there for a protracted period of time. Just put it on the side.

The positives:

1. You cast a shadow
helpfulPercent: you can see your legs and you have a personality. (THANK YOU)\n\n2. The AI. This is one time when no one can complain about the crappy AI. The zombie AI is doing exactly what it is supposed to doing
votesHelpful: being zombie. Plus there are some zombies with different social behavior. Some remain dormant only to wake up when you are next to them
votesTotal: some charge
votesFunny: some are hard to kill and some jump at you when you open a door. I wish there were some zombies that were peaceful though
commentsCount: just for fun.\n\n3. Great battle system
column16: reminiscent of The Dark Messiah. You get to kick and you get to slash. Not sure if parrying or blocking the attacks is going to be available for upgrade later. However
column17: you cannot hack and slash all the time
column18: because your stamina runs out. And even though the stamina runs out pretty slowly sometimes you have to time your hits. Greater incentive is also given towards aiming for the head since your weapons will deteriorate with each wasted blow. The auto-aim will do the job for you though. At first I felt insulted that yet another console driven game was shoving auto-aim in my face but I got used to it. Not only that
column19: the auto-aim is enabled even when you stand above a dead zombie. You can still hack their particular body parts to pieces.\n\n4. For the maximum immersion
column20: you can turn off the enemy health pop ups
column22:
the auto-aim as well as the enemy level indicator.

5. The motion blur is always welcome.

6. Plenty of upgrades for your character your weapons and other miscellaneous things. Unlike in Borderlands
column23: you CAN take on some enemies above your level and manage to kill them.\n\n7. Plenty of scavenging is involved
column24:
sometimes you get to find rare items that cost a lot of $.

8. The driving of the rare few vehicles is smooth.

9. Some decent use of environments.

10. The cover system reminiscent of the Killzone franchise is very lovable and realistic.

11. Co-op is fun as advertised.

On another note
column25: it turns out that the best non-modded melee weapon so far is the cleaver. One slash and the head comes off. What I also liked is that every kill feels like you are actually killing someone or something
column26:
unlike in Left4Dead where the simple mowing down of hundreds of zombies in the matter of minutes stays fun but quickly turns generic

The bottom line is that the game itself does not really play as a survival horror game but as an arcade beat'em up with some new elements. Take that for what it is worth.

That is all.

Updated. 9-9-11.

I found myself enjoying the game more by playing alone rather than co-op. Your co-op buddies tend to either lag behind or run too far out ahead. I prefer playing alone at night with the headset on

reviewText:
Dead Island is a 2011 action role-playing survival horror video game developed by Polish developer Techland and published by German studio Deep Silver for Microsoft Windows, Linux, OS X, PlayStation 3, and Xbox 360. It is centered on the challenge of surviving a zombie-infested open world island with a major emphasis on melee combat. It was originally announced at E3 2006 but was pushed back to 2011. It was released on 6 September 2011 in North America, 9 September 2011 in the PAL regions and 20 October 2011 in Japan. A stand-alone expansion, Dead Island: Riptide, was released in 2013. A spin-off, Escape Dead Island, was released on 18 November 2014. A sequel, Dead Island 2, is set to be released in 2016.

Dead Island features an apparent open world roaming, divided by relatively large areas, and played from a first-person perspective. Most of the gameplay is built around combat and completing quests. Dead Island is an action role-playing game and uses experience-based gameplay. The player earns XP by completing tasks and killing enemies. Upon leveling up, the player gains health and stamina, and can invest one skill point into a skill tree and level up one of their skills.

Combat is carried out through either physical attacks or through the use of melee weapons and firearms. Melee weapons are emphasized[8] to the point that firearms are not available for the first quarter of the game, and consist of blunt and bladed weapons. Melee weapons can also be thrown at targets at any point in the game. Weapons are randomly generated and positioned in predetermined locations as well as found on some enemies; they have unique stats which are generally based on the player's current level. Each weapon can be upgraded three times to increase its stats, and most weapons can be modded" - customized based on a blueprint to add special features
date: such as nails or electrified blades
recommended: and poison.[8] These weapons will wear out from constant usage and require repairs and careful use.\n\nThere is also a stamina bar
hoursPlayed: meaning that after a set amount of physical action
voteText: such as running

votesHelpful: or swinging a weapon
votesTotal: the character needs to stop to regain his or her stamina bar
votesFunny: meaning that having a fight with a high level zombie will result in you often running out of stamina and getting killed. The game features "special class" zombies
commentsCount: which are more powerful than the standard zombie. Players need to use flashlights in dark areas and during night-time sections
column16: adding suspense.\n\nZombies in the game have different abilities
column17: such as the Walkers being Romero style zombies and the Infected being 28 Days Later style running zombies. There are also other special zombies being Left 4 Dead style.\n\nRate: 11/10"

reviewText:
Have you ever heard of a game that requires you to change your regional settings in your Windows OS in order to function properly (i.e., to be able to display any UI texts in-game as well as have your mouse pointer function normally)? No? Well, now you have.

In addition, there are several technical issues which you need to attend to manually (and by doing some research and using a third party tool for the most basic configurations...).

This game is a pile of trash. I purchased it when it was on sale, and after investing hours in doing online research on several of said issues, I decided to have it refunded.

Seriously, what kind of nonsense is that? The game is not even brand new, so you would expect it to have been patched by now to fix the most severe bugs. Sad, really.

Don't buy.

reviewText:
I got Dead Island in a bundle. I’ve bought so many game bundles, I can’t remember which one it was in. But in most game bundles there are three kinds of games: the ones you’re buying the bundle for, the ones you might play since you’re getting them in the bundle, and the ones you know you’ll never touch. When I got Dead Island, I thought I’d at least give it a shot some time, but now I kind of wish I hadn’t.

Hit zombies. Repeat until bored.

Dead Island would’ve disappeared into the bargain bins without a glance if it hadn’t been for its infamously misleading trailer, which turned out to have nothing to do with the actual game. This shouldn’t have surprised anybody, but somehow it meant that Dead Island got a lot more attention on release than it deserved, so it was an effective marketing strategy. If you think games journalists would know better by now, you don’t know anything about games journalism.

In any case, Dead Island is pretty much worthless garbage. It has an incredibly boring open world, devoid of anything even gesturing at character, and nothing much to do in it but an endless succession of fetch and kill quests. The combat has some interesting ideas, but it doesn’t make up for the lack of any imagination or even ambition in the rest of the game. Even as part of a bundle, Dead Island isn’t just poor value, it’s negative value. I don’t want my money back, I want to be paid for the time I’ve lost playing this game.

http://macrotransactions.wordpress.com/2013/10/12/200-games-200-words-10-dead-island/

reviewText:
Who doesn't dream of taking vacations to a paradise island ? ME.
I'm now so freaking scared that this happens when I go.

First of all, I was following this game since the first trailer and I couldn't wait it to be released.
The story goes in an Island infected by a virus, only 4 survivors are going to team up to escape the Island. It's not the best point of the game but, does Pac Man has a story to run over ghosts ? It's still a fun game to me.
Anyway, at the time the game got released, the design of the map was just amazingly beautiful, jumping inside waterpools, trying to get on the slides, climbing on a tree for the lol.
The game is working almost like a MMORPG, you have a system of levels and skills to learn. It's not really hard to level up if you do the side quests, though some are repeatable. So who says MMORPG says it's mainly coop to be enjoyed.

The bad parts of this game are, first, the VAC that is completely USELESS, the game itself helps you to cheat by using glitches, the first one was after the 1st update, you could get unlimited money by selling and buying weapons that are above the level max.
Mods created by players of the community are also available to modify the game and that should be considered as a potential cheat since mine is disabling the gravity and the stamina, I can also send zombies to fly with a punch.

Also, Most of the people here are saying that this game is bad because it's repetitive, has clunky controls, bad graphics.
Man, aslong the game is not called Battlefield Island: Modern Warfare 98, it's bad.

When it's clunky, you should know that you can craft weapons.
When it's repetitive, you should find out side quest to get you guns.
When it has bad graphics, it has a lot of glitches that you can use to make fun with. (Check my screenshots)
And there is 3 maps, I spoil: Island, Town, Jungle. Special zombies come over in the new maps you discover.
You have over 100 IDs to find in all the maps, 5 skulls to find to unlock the electric hand to charge the zombies and make them fly as on Bioshock.

- Finally, if you decide to buy this game to play alone, don't take this game.
If you are going to play with a friend, you should have fun in a game, if you play Dota and that you think you're unbeatable in any game, zombies in this one will beat your ♥♥♥ up. :3

reviewText:
This game was awesome.. for the first hours.. the first time i played it.. years ago. Then i stopped..

I picked it up again..later.. replayed the start ..then a  bit more... Then i stopped...

I picked it up later, witha  buddy.. we played a bit more... Then we stopped..

I rescently picked it up again.. with 3 friends.. determined to clear this game, for good! Then we didin't stop! (group powa)

We laughted..a lot.. at the game.. at the bugs..problems.. everything wrong with it..

We raged.. at the sewers.. repetion.. lack of interesting story... why are we.. IC going to pick up the necklace fo some random chick..in a waterfall? (it was on the bus btw.. thanks for trying) for money? please its the end of the world!

The game is at it's best early on and ..it only.. goes downhill from there.. like a snowball of puke.. rolling down puke mountain!

The game was most likely a breakthrough when it first came out.. but it did not age well at all.. and none of us would have even finished it on our own without the motivation of being 4 guys having fun and beating this game!

We finished it.. after one person in the party one-shotted the last boss. One of us lvl 47.. the others lvl 30.. because xp shared..balance.. etc..

The game tried hard, but id rather recomend Dying Light and telling you guys to skip this one!

have fun not playing this!

+Beautiful graphics and scenary
+Zombies are actually tougher as the game progresses and will attack you in groups.
+Stamina mechanic keeps the combat interesting and refreshing.
+Decent multiplayer game.

Cons:
-Sometimes the game feels too tough especially in singleplayer.
-Escort mission ai is really annoying, horribly design and keeps saying the same  5 lines throughout the mission.
-Has the potential to have a stealth mechanic but it is not implemented in the game.
-Horrible targetting system, most of the time when you're trying to hit a zombie who is in front of you, you will hit the other zombies especially the ones who are laying down.
-Most of the time the items you're holding will automatically switch with the item that you just picked up (especially alcohol).
-The melee weapons that you throw sometimes went into the ground which makes it nearly impossible to retrieve.

The gameplay and design of the game are interesting but the horrible targetting system and ai are so bad that I wouldn't recommend anyone buying this game unless its on sale for less than $2.

reviewText:
Dead Island is a cross between Borderlands and System Shock 2 in a lush tropical setting infested by the zombified infected.  On paper, that sounds like it should make for an amazingly fun title, but the reality doesn't line up.

This is a bug-infested game that needed a bit more polish.  For example, the cursor on the unnecessarily convoluted UI menus, for example, is horribly sluggish and cannot be adjusted.  If you have more than one monitor, there's a chance the cursor will not be locked down and will float off to another monitor mid-combat, causing the game to lose context and return to the desktop -- meanwhile, the game does not pause, leaving you free to be eaten alive while you scramble to bring the game back into focus.

Serious bugs aside, a fan-created patch to disable weapon degredation and adjust enemy AI is almost required to make it playable.

Most of the enjoyment comes from assaulting the undead with the various weapons and vehicles -- and it IS fun...for a while.

reviewText:
Without a doubt the trailer for this game was one of most captivating I have seen in almost 2 decades of gaming.

The game is an action RPG in which you earn experience in order to level up your characters abilities. Each character has their own unique ability.

The atmosphere is very dark, depressing and creepy even in broad daylight. I have played a myriad of zombie games but I can say that this one is one of the few that really makes you feel truly alone and surrounded. It is very easy to get too over zealous and then swarmed by zombies.

Initially the co-op suffered greatly with frequent drop outs and connection issues. However, it was resolved eventually.

The game does have its bugs but its worth a play through. Get it on a steam sale and you shouldn't be disappointed.

reviewText: I'd give Dead Island a much more enthusiastic recommendation if it weren't for the completely over-the-top swearing--especially the constant blasphemy, which I find to be intolerable. Sure people swear--especially in extreme situations, which this is--but the language jars one out of the story rather than immerses. It's unnecessary, juvenile and annoying--not to mention downright disgusting when it comes to the endless curses of the Lord, Jesus Christ.\n\nThat aside, I actually really enjoy this game. It's nice to be back in a situation that actually feels like survival horror again. The rpg element is a great twist that keeps the idea of zombies in a video game--again--quite fresh. There's a ton of content, the graphics are strong, if somewhat repetitive, and the ambient nature of the game goes a long way to setting a really cool tone for a horror game. A bit clunky feeling at times, less than intuitive at others, but worth a look if you've got a friend to explore the island with.

reviewText:
This was a game that I downloaded because I had heard great things about it, and, as I expected, the game was a great one. Techland managed to create the most realistic zombie fighting game I have played in a long time, with the weapon duribility system and stamina system. It's truthfully a masterpiece in the zombie horror catagory that I would reccommend to anyone.

There is a downside, however. I, personally, felt as though the game started running a bit slowly after the first act. The system of moving around and fighting zombies and doing quests felt a bit tedious, and the plot wasn't all that engaging. It got a bit dry towards the end so much that I felt as if I just needed to rush through the final act. Regardless of that one fault, the game was an enjoyable experience that I'm glad I took the time to do.

As I am an acheivement hunter, I took a look at that aspect of the game as well. The acheivements for the game are very reasonable and fun. Some are tricky and require skill whereas some are just clever. However, the game hit the bottom of my list when it came to acheivements for two reasons. First, there is one acheivement that requires you to have a X-Box controller to get, which, in my opinion, is quite the slap in the face to someone who is playing via the computer. The second reason, and it may just be me, is that one of the acheivements in the game didn't trigger for me. I ended up without one of the co-op acheivements due to some unknown reason. All in all the acheivements were a disappointment due to these two blunders.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I really wanted this game to live up to the awesome trailer we all saw.  You know the one - the reversed, slow motion of the little girl falling from the hotel room window.  We all wanted a zombie game to capture the frenzied, improvised nature of surviving in a zombie apocolypse while feeling a real emotional impact of seeing people becoming infected and turning.  I fell for the old trick of watching a cinematic and thinking it pertained to what the game would actually be like.  Gotta say, I was disappointed.

That's not to say the game didn't have it's merits.  If you play it through on singleplayer then there are scenes which you feel cornered and you're not sure you're going to make it.  It does have a bit of immersion to it.  That goes away when you play it with other people are see the wonky animations your characters make, or if you happen to catch the shadow of your character while sprinting doing a ridiculous arm flail we once saw in a leaked version of the incomplete game (it's probably still around on youtube somewhere).

For all that I'm ♥♥♥♥♥ing and moaning about it, I still played it through to the end.  It felt more satisfying to do it alone though.  Having competent team mates who you've played plenty of online games with before makes the game easy, which ruins the attempted survival-orientated theme they were going for.  The few darkened, claustrophic parts of the game really worked well in my opinion.  Unfortunately most of the game felt too.. bright, the zombies too slow, resources too frequent.

It's at least a step in right direction.  I'm still waiting for a first person zombie game to hit me right in the feels while putting me in the thick of it.
