reviewText:
Firstly i used to have this game on the xbox 360 along with riptide once it came out and had well over my fair share of hours lost on it haha.
In all honestly this is by far the best first person zombie horror game out there in my opinion, this game was built for a pad so if you've not used one i would recommend you try it!
The analog control setting with the pad is so immersive allowing you to swing your melee weapon in any direction. By using the right analog stick and left trigger you will ready your weapon then cut or bash whichever bodypart you like from breaking bones with blunt weapons to slicing off limbs joint by joint, the blood and gore is very well done and damage effects on the zombies are incredible, giving a wide range of diffrents types from walkers to infected to rammers and suiciders and alot more.
The characters themselves feel rather stiff in this first game when attempting the strafe right or left and senstivity could do with being allowed a little faster but i guess you can only turn your head so fast with snapping your neck. This however doesnt make the game unbareable or annyoing.
You have a choice of four diffrent playable characters in the Dead Island installment and 6 in Dead Island Riptide. Each has thier own unique skill set tree depending on what you'd rather slay your zombies with, this however doesnt mean just because your a blunt user you only have to use hhammers and baseball bats ect but you wont be as effective with bladed weapons but you can still kill zombies effectively. Again unfortunatly the first game rather under powered most of the firearms  leaving you with putting 6 or so magnum rounds into a zombies head before it dies, this however was changed drmatically in the second installment allowing for firearms to prove more effective with headshots against the living dead.
Weapons come in a very wide range from crowbars, baseball bats, slegehammers, mauls, batons, hanbos, knuckledustters, machetes, knifes, katanas, tantos, kukris, fireaxes, double blades and much more giving you plenty of variety to try out, each weapon is broken down into several catorgories with damage, force, durability, handling. Damage being for bladed wepaons, force for blunt weapons, the higher the force the more knockback the weapon will have. Handling depends on how many swings  your chracter will get before becoming fatigued, so the higher the handling the more swings you will have. Duriability is pretty straight forward being with the higher the durability the btter condition your wepon will stay after mulitple hits.
Repair benches are quite common throughout the world giving you a chance to repair your items back to full for a cost, the rarer the weapon the more it willl cost to repair. On that note many weapons can be modded with devastating effects from electricution to sickness effects, each mod is obtained either by finding in the various locations or earing as part of a reward upon completing a quest. You may also choose not to mod anything out of the ordinary like myself and keep it to the more realistic mods like the barbed wired mod or the glazed mod which consist of a gluey rag wrapped around a blunt object,covered in glue then rolled in shards of broken glass for a brutal bleeding effect.
Anyway thats all from me and my review on dead island and hope any of you that managed to read all the way through then thank you for taking the time to read this. Happy Gaming all.

reviewText: Dead Island is an extremely buggy game that suffers from texture pop-in and a HORRIBLE story that drags on for way too long. Yet I love it. In the case of video games, I greatly value gameplay over plot, and this game has great gameplay. It's fun to turn zombies into mush with a variety of unique and crazy weapons. It's fun to curbstomp a corpse and watch its head splatter. And the whole game is very entertaining with a friend. That can be said about almost any game, but it's especially true for Dead Island. I just finished a playthrough with a friend and not only was it enjoyable to splatter undead together, but it makes the game much easier. If you plan on playing this game through in single player, you might have a bad time. It is very difficult in certain areas.\n\nThis game gets a lot of hate, and while it is deserving of some of it, enjoyment can still be found in this title. I recommend grabbing this during a sale, if you have a buddy who's interested in playing as well.

reviewText:
Dead Island is easily one of the strangest games I've played that actively attempts to be a game rather than a spectacle. It does not easily fit into any genre I regularly peruse, and its bizarre list of consolization issues and strengths make it hard to look at from any one angle.

First and foremost, Dead Island is about killing zombies. This is nothing short of blatantly obvious. It is in this, however, that its unusually robust, yet succinct tactical depth is present; arms can be broken with blunt weapons or knives, or hacked off with machetes or axes. Enemies thrown to the floor take additional damage from a weapon's force attribute, while some enemies introduced early on have head or body armor. Combined with its (incredibly awkward) first person shooter elements, it makes for a unique experience, to say the least.

This uniqueness, however, is part of its shortcomings. Aim assist - even for melee weapons! - is permanently active with no option to disable it, making firearms - particularly with the combination of sticky aiming and partial auto-aim - clumsy and borderline painful to use for shooter veterans. RPG mechanics feel practically tacked on, with run-of-the-mill character-specific skills, levelling, and equipment levels rippling the player's awkwardly out-of-place stockpile of money throughout the game. Floaty movement, some unbindable commands, and general sloppiness of its stability lend much credibility to it being a bad console port.

Its artistic side is yet again another moment of individual genius clashing against individual oddity. The locale is relatively novel for a zombie apocalypse-styled game, featuring rundown slums, dense jungles, and beachfront resorts. Its depiction of the undead is undoubtedly graphic, and a special mutilated" sub-skin for nearly every zombie adds much to the feeling of hacking apart reanimated corpses. The same technique used
recommended: can be the source of visual oddities; all severed heads are the same
voteText: badly damaged limbs shrivel up confusingly to emulate tissue loss
helpfulPercent: and incendiary weapons will turn enemies pitch black
votesHelpful: leading more to a dark skinned or even glossy appearance rather than burnt. Maps feature many a misplaced prop embedded in scenery or distended from scenery it was intended to be aligned with. This list continues for many things in the game.\n\nOverall
votesTotal: however
votesFunny: Dead Island is an interesting
commentsCount: enjoyable game with its own merits worthy of praise and shortcomings to be on the lookout for. Its modding capacity
column16: unfortunately
column17: is relatively scant
column18: but its fairly robust cooperative play may well make up for that."

reviewText: I enjoyed playing dead island, but one major problem is that when you get seperated from your team(assuming you're playing multi-player) the zombies are still at multi-player level, so unless you are way above level or have incredibly good weapons, you are most likely to die, that means that you have to use teamwork, which I wasn't the best at. But one of the things I really enjoyed about the game was the crafting. I really liked having to collect the supplies needed to make the weapon, and then finnaly getting to a workbench to build the badass item. The combat is absolutely terrifying and you actually feel as if you are being chased by a swarm of zombies trying to rip your head off. The weapons are fun to play with and awesome, like a chainsaw beheading a monster while its on fire. I especially liked the variation in  the different weapons, from beheading 4 zombies at once with a four bladed fire-dagger to bashing one's brain in and watching it melt with your skin-blistering poison knuckle-duster. At the beggining, each player has to do their own introduction mission in a hotel, which I found very creepy. The first zombie combat starts after you have walked along a corridor blocked by a baggage trolley, so you have to go past through a door to the side, in which, you have to turn your torch on so it seems even more scary because it reminds you that it is actually incredibly dark in there. After you get out of the room, which you can loot to its theoretical bone, you continue along the corridor to come to a door that leads to the open where there is a cutscene that you see some undead lunge off the balcony above. you then turn around and go to the broken elevator and open the hatch.  There is then another cutscene of the elevator falling down the shaft. It suddenly stops and two zombies start charging you while you're on the ground but luckily the lift falls another few feet. Then you hear a voice over the lift speaker telling you to do exactly as it says and to get a weapon from the maitenance room. You then crouch walk out of the lift and across a balcony and sprint down a corridor, get chased back down by infected, blah blah blah, and you finish after another cutscene. You may think that the cutscenes were insane in that but they are actually quite important. I haven't bought any of the DLC, so I can't review it, sry. I enjoyed exploring the different areas, like finding all of the tiny branches of tiny huts along the very large and blue coast. Although, they just HAD to include the tired, worn cliche of a level in the sewers. But they do introduce the floater in there at the beginning, which is basically a thug (a tank)who can puke on you, what a dull enemy. I would certainly reccomend this game, I haven't got Riptide yet, but I really hope that they improved those rather large cons in the game, but kept the pros almost the same, but it needs to change the gameplay slightly so it actually afs something to this game so it isn't just copy-pasted onto a different disk/download. When rating it I would give it 8/10 because of those major problems with it.

reviewText:
As far as Zombie Survival goes? It's one of, if not the best, zombie game on the market right now.  It's really a lot of fun to play with friends, too.

On launch it had some horrendous bugs, such as dying from kicking beachballs at times and awful net code.  But they did a decent job of patching and took care of them at a decent speed.

You'll find quests all over the various areas, a number of weapons, and a unique play style for each character.   It really shines when you play with friends, though.   The joy of just mulching through hordes of Zombies and dealing with the special infected with buddies is hard to rival.

As a coop game it is phenomenal.

reviewText: I'd give Dead Island a much more enthusiastic recommendation if it weren't for the completely over-the-top swearing--especially the constant blasphemy, which I find to be intolerable. Sure people swear--especially in extreme situations, which this is--but the language jars one out of the story rather than immerses. It's unnecessary, juvenile and annoying--not to mention downright disgusting when it comes to the endless curses of the Lord, Jesus Christ.\n\nThat aside, I actually really enjoy this game. It's nice to be back in a situation that actually feels like survival horror again. The rpg element is a great twist that keeps the idea of zombies in a video game--again--quite fresh. There's a ton of content, the graphics are strong, if somewhat repetitive, and the ambient nature of the game goes a long way to setting a really cool tone for a horror game. A bit clunky feeling at times, less than intuitive at others, but worth a look if you've got a friend to explore the island with.

reviewText:
Firstly i used to have this game on the xbox 360 along with riptide once it came out and had well over my fair share of hours lost on it haha.
In all honestly this is by far the best first person zombie horror game out there in my opinion, this game was built for a pad so if you've not used one i would recommend you try it!
The analog control setting with the pad is so immersive allowing you to swing your melee weapon in any direction. By using the right analog stick and left trigger you will ready your weapon then cut or bash whichever bodypart you like from breaking bones with blunt weapons to slicing off limbs joint by joint, the blood and gore is very well done and damage effects on the zombies are incredible, giving a wide range of diffrents types from walkers to infected to rammers and suiciders and alot more.
The characters themselves feel rather stiff in this first game when attempting the strafe right or left and senstivity could do with being allowed a little faster but i guess you can only turn your head so fast with snapping your neck. This however doesnt make the game unbareable or annyoing.
You have a choice of four diffrent playable characters in the Dead Island installment and 6 in Dead Island Riptide. Each has thier own unique skill set tree depending on what you'd rather slay your zombies with, this however doesnt mean just because your a blunt user you only have to use hhammers and baseball bats ect but you wont be as effective with bladed weapons but you can still kill zombies effectively. Again unfortunatly the first game rather under powered most of the firearms  leaving you with putting 6 or so magnum rounds into a zombies head before it dies, this however was changed drmatically in the second installment allowing for firearms to prove more effective with headshots against the living dead.
Weapons come in a very wide range from crowbars, baseball bats, slegehammers, mauls, batons, hanbos, knuckledustters, machetes, knifes, katanas, tantos, kukris, fireaxes, double blades and much more giving you plenty of variety to try out, each weapon is broken down into several catorgories with damage, force, durability, handling. Damage being for bladed wepaons, force for blunt weapons, the higher the force the more knockback the weapon will have. Handling depends on how many swings  your chracter will get before becoming fatigued, so the higher the handling the more swings you will have. Duriability is pretty straight forward being with the higher the durability the btter condition your wepon will stay after mulitple hits.
Repair benches are quite common throughout the world giving you a chance to repair your items back to full for a cost, the rarer the weapon the more it willl cost to repair. On that note many weapons can be modded with devastating effects from electricution to sickness effects, each mod is obtained either by finding in the various locations or earing as part of a reward upon completing a quest. You may also choose not to mod anything out of the ordinary like myself and keep it to the more realistic mods like the barbed wired mod or the glazed mod which consist of a gluey rag wrapped around a blunt object,covered in glue then rolled in shards of broken glass for a brutal bleeding effect.
Anyway thats all from me and my review on dead island and hope any of you that managed to read all the way through then thank you for taking the time to read this. Happy Gaming all.

reviewText: Dead Island is your standard zombie killing fair with a multiplayer element and moderately well told story revolving the survival of the remaining guests on the somewhat undead island. The game plays quite well, and although the multiplayer is rudimentary it is servicable for drop in/out play. The story is nothing stellar and may bore some audiences but the survival elements make up for this shortcoming. As you explore the island you will meet various survivors with unique personalities that give the player motivation to continue forward. The visuals in this game are also quite well done, and if you ever get a moments break from the zombie hordes you will find yourself in a beautiful world. The downfalls however relate to some of the core gameplay elements, the combat itself and skill-tree progression system hurt the game more than enhance it, and considering you spend the vast majority of the game fighting for survival this is nothing to take lightly. One example of such is the customization of weapons and the workbench which will consume large amounts of your time repairing or upgrading weapons based on what you find, an intriguing concept but weapons break (condition decay) too easily and most function in the same manner despite forcing you to use select weapons based on the character you select or your skilltree. This hurts the game drastically, almost to the point of making the game worth skipping. As such I can't recommend this game, nor can I recommend passing on it, it may be an enjoyable experience with friends but it is ultimately a potentially great game marred by poor gameplay.

reviewText:
Initially, I would have given this game a thumbs down. I played it when it was first released and bug-laden, prior to its appearance on Steam. Dead Island was clearly rushed to release, and a no-clip mode was enabled by default. The first patch to fix that particular issue was released reasonably fast.

I was mostly disappointed by Dead Island, because when it was first announced, I thought the idea of merging GTA/Saints Row freeroam, Zombie Survival, and RPG elements together was brilliant. I mean, these are all things I've enjoyed.
The idea was excellent, but the execution was rather poor.

Today, most bugs have been patched out, and the core gameplay remains. The environments aren't bad, and I like the character designs, but there's still the issue of terrible player animations. To see what I mean, try running or turning or jumping while starting at your shadow or feet. Some of the voice acting is also fairly lackluster.

Despite all these things, if a game is still at least playable, and has good to decent core gameplay, I have the ability to enjoy it for what it is. And this is a good case: I did enjoy Dead Island overall.
It could easily have been much MUCH more, but I still enjoyed it.

reviewText: While this game had it's problems at initial launch, the concept of an open world zombie apocalypse was enough to keep me grinding through the bugs.  And it was WELL WORTH IT!  The end result was a game that in my opinion was long over due, no one made a zombie game that promised as much as this!!  Sure there are scarier titles like Resident Evil, or even more mainstream such as Dead Rising, This was the zombie game of choice, and I would still take this style of zombie and gameplay over Dying Light.\n\nVery few reasons to not like this game, such as Headshots not counting.  Mods exist for this reason and that issue has been long since addressed by the comunity.  A very odd and frustrating ending, but the hours of sheer enjoyment all before this more than make up for such a small setback!  And of course the dreaded special undead, which is something that somehow every zombie game developer seems to deem necessary!  Quite honestly I feel this game will only be topped by the (highly anticipated by myself) sequel Dead Island 2.  Which in my opinion cannot be released soon enough!  The classic zombie formula is far too much fun a concept to be left unconsidered by even the biggest devleopers, I can't get the thought out of my head that Ubisoft using the FarCry build could make one of the Ultimate Zombie games of our time.  You may call me crazy, but while it is" a better quality game
date: L4D has nothing on Dead Island.  No one gives you the full zombie apocalypse survival experience that Dead Island gives you
hoursPlayed: helping or not helping other survivors

helpfulPercent: maintaining and upgrading weapons

votesFunny: etc etc.\n\nSo while I keep dreaming of the "perfect" Zombie apocalypse with classic zombies theme'd survival experience

reviewText: Действие Dead Island происходит на открытом острове. В игре большая часть арсенала состоит из оружия ближнего боя – топоров, мачете, бейсбольных бит, бензопил и так далее.  Огнестрельное оружие тоже имеется.  Ролевая система в игре состоит из привычного набора уровней, повышения геройских параметров. Но постепенно по мере прокачки будут открываться новые боевые способности.  В сюжетную кампанию игры вплетен кооператив на четверых. Народ может присоединиться к игре в любой момент и взять в свои руки управление одним из персонажей. Моя оценка 7/10.

reviewText:
I'm picky when it comes to zombie games and/or movies but this is perfect for the genre , there has always needed to be a zombie rpg.
There are a few glitchy moments in the game but easily over looked ones and I  found  the UI a little slow but manageable.
One thing confused me every time though , the car steering wheel is on the right side! lol, not used to that in the US.
Online is co-op and anyone can join your game if you leave it open but there's an option to turn it off and just play solo as well.

Overall , it's a fun game with a good amount of quests and replay value .

voteText:
Windows 64 rates it a 7.9/8.0 so it runs fairly well.  Not any significant problems.  Some glitchouts at some rocky terrain areas and such.  Nothing significant.

Cons
A slowdown period through the sewers that got annoying.  That's about it for me.  The ending had its moments.  My coop partner had a horribly overpowered one-hit kill weapon at the final boss battle that sort of made the ending flat for me.  That was about it.

Good luck and have fun.

Thanks for reading."

reviewText: if you're a zombie game fan, you'll do well with giving this a fair shake.  IWhen it first hit, it definitely had it's bugs, but the last patch really smoothed things out.  Intended for multiplayer, but singleplayer is my personal recommendation if you're looking for immersion.  Word of warning, don't expect a FPS.  Unless that S stands for slashing, stabbing, or smashing.  You'll eventually come across firearms, but you'll need ammo and in true survival horror fashion, it's not going to just fall in your lap.  You will either steal it from other survivors or make your own.  Just remember, gunfire draws attention, and the zombies are plentiful.

reviewText: This game is a mixed bag. On one hand, it's a fairly fun change of pace from most zombie/shooters, with RPG elements and good damage models. It's fun with friends, but that could be said about most things. The quests and multiplayer functions work out fairly well, and it can be a decent challenge at times.\n\nOn the other hand, people will naturally and unintentionally out-level each other, making things harder. Some quests, items, and other things will bug out, disappear, freeze or require a restart, but it rarely was a problem that couldnt be solved. The characters and story are complete crap, forgettable and making me want L4D2's in that regard. Worth it on sale, if you have friends that for sure will stick with you through it, or if you -really- like zombies, then i spose it's tolerable.

reviewText:
Pros:
+ Using a hammer smashes zombies and a sword slices zombies - very satisfying
+ Skill trees are intuitive
+ Each character skill trees have some overlap so you don't necessarily need to change characters for a different play style or experience
+ Crafting is somewhat flexible
+ Difficulty scales with level
+ Most of the bugs from the first two-three months of release have been fixed

Cons:
- Clunky user interface at times
- Going back to other areas you've already visited
- Default movement and run speed feels sluggish
- Some of the super abilities feel uninspired
- Theres a greater dependance on what weapons you use and the proximity of the level of the monsters you are fighting.  (You can't really keep a favorite weapon and level it up without crafting a new one)
- DLC is not worth getting

reviewText: Dead Island is your standard zombie killing fair with a multiplayer element and moderately well told story revolving the survival of the remaining guests on the somewhat undead island. The game plays quite well, and although the multiplayer is rudimentary it is servicable for drop in/out play. The story is nothing stellar and may bore some audiences but the survival elements make up for this shortcoming. As you explore the island you will meet various survivors with unique personalities that give the player motivation to continue forward. The visuals in this game are also quite well done, and if you ever get a moments break from the zombie hordes you will find yourself in a beautiful world. The downfalls however relate to some of the core gameplay elements, the combat itself and skill-tree progression system hurt the game more than enhance it, and considering you spend the vast majority of the game fighting for survival this is nothing to take lightly. One example of such is the customization of weapons and the workbench which will consume large amounts of your time repairing or upgrading weapons based on what you find, an intriguing concept but weapons break (condition decay) too easily and most function in the same manner despite forcing you to use select weapons based on the character you select or your skilltree. This hurts the game drastically, almost to the point of making the game worth skipping. As such I can't recommend this game, nor can I recommend passing on it, it may be an enjoyable experience with friends but it is ultimately a potentially great game marred by poor gameplay.

reviewText: Welcome to the tropical paradise Island known as Banoi. Blue skies, clear waters, beautiful people, Music, culture, drugs alcohol sex, & Zombies! That’s right. You’ll venture thru the Island as one of the unsuspecting 4 people that traveled to paradise for work. You will interact with many characters during your travels as you’ll be tasked to help others and search for survivors. This first person Zombie hack&slash, gun&run will keep your heart pounding and raise the hair on the back of your neck. There are limited # of weapons that you can modify and you’ll be able to drive some vehicles killing any Zombie that stands in your way. Dead Island auto saves (check point) so you may continue again at a later time. The Island is very large, & there is tons to do. This all-round Zombie fest is a must have. Single player or Multiplayer, keyboard or controller enabled. Check hints often for achievement’s & actions.

reviewText: So very beautiful game! In my play time I died many times because I was admiring view and zombies managed to sneak on me, haha! But really the island is very beautiful and makes me want to travel some place tropical. I only got to play small part of story but it seemed interesting and there was lot of things to do, many side quests and much to explore. Many different type of weapons to choose from too and you even got to built some more if you got blue print and material for them. Bad thing was that weapons broke too easily and that was bad. Running zombies over with car was best entertainment! Very gory too and I know some people like that in a game.\nI liked that you got to pick what sort of character you play with. All four choices had good strenghts and felt balanced so it was hard to decide who was my favourite. Killing zombies was buggy a lot of times because zombies seemed to teleport from side to side and I think that would have started to be annoying in more difficult missions later but it did not bother me much. It was also great that you could join friends game when you wanted and do things together. That was very nice touch to the game. I really liked this game and I wish I would had more time to play it!

reviewText:
Forget the trailer: Dead Island is Borderlands crossed with Left 4 Dead. The story is bad and the characters are barely one-dimensional, but Dead Island still manages to be a compelling game, thanks in part to its visceral combat and amusing weapons.

As mentioned, Dead Island is a lot like Borderlands: you're set down in a large open environment and have to complete a variety of simple quests in order to advance the storyline and gain experience points to upgrade your character. But where Borderlands dealt mostly with guns, Dead Island features a very heavy focus on melee combat. The combat looks and sounds nasty, as heads and limbs can be cut off and smashed apart. The fighting is much better if you have an Xbox 360 gamepad since the controller allows for the aiming of swings, meaning you can target specific body parts on zombies and make them go flying with a well-placed weapon strike.

Dead Island has things wrong with it, to be sure: bad voice-acting, bad dialog, weird-looking human characters, and annoying bugs, in particular some horrendous clipping that sees weapons sink into the ground and zombies able to strike you through the corners of buildings or even even other zombies. This stuff is annoying.

But at the same time, Dead Island is very playable: the environments are detailed, and the sound effects are great. It's also fun leveling up your character and searching the island for weapon blueprints that will electrocute zombies or set them on fire. And even though the story is bad, you'll want to keep playing to the end just to see how everything turns out.

Dead Island also features co-op play for up to four players and it's pretty easy to set up and join a co-op game, although if you want to play solo you still can. The one problem with the co-op in Dead Island is that enemies level to the highest-level player in the game, meaning a low-level player might end up in a game with very tough enemies. To avoid this, it's best to play with friends at around the same level you are.

Dead Island has a lot of flaws and one has to be willing to tolerate them if they want to have fun. But there's fun to be had here just the same.

It’s a good game, just that.
The story is simply boring, same generic story about zombies. One thing that I need to give emphasis is the same generic reason the main character is immune to the virus, because them blood type is negative O… CLASSIC. The story develop is that simple, too. Those improvements can make the weapons work totally different, my favorite weapon is the ripper baseball bat and you can cut everything with this.
The infected is really overpower, I was scary when I hearded more than one infected coming, because those ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥ is unstoppable.

I don't have anything to say about the soundtrack, It isn't amazing, but it isn't bad.

I just recommend this game because of the gameplay.

That’s sound I haven't enjoyed the game, but I have.

reviewText:
Dead Island is a mixed bag.  Its combat is fun in places, the land is open with lots of room for discovery, searching, looting, and finding secrets, and there are some mechanics in place to draw out the very lengthy game play.  All in all it was very fun and I beat the game in just over 45 hours on my first play through, so there was definitely some value in purchasing this title.

However, the characters were bland and lifeless, the story was almost interesting but managed to fall short of really being anything unique or even explaining existing zombie lore.  The roads are so short and overly populated with debris that driving should have been left out completely.  The combat suffers greatly from balance issues.  And, worst of all, the game is so absolutely full of bugs that its barely playable.

A major patch could boost the game into epic status, but without that effort I recommend this game assuming it comes in a deep discount bundle as I have seen it of late.  Its much easier to forgive the onslaught of bugs and game issues when you get a deal ;)
